entry.title: Unlocking a Cleaner and Greener Energy Future with AI
entry.content:
The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) mandate rapid clean energy adoption to combat climate change. However, many utilities still face hurdles integrating renewables such as solar, wind, and hydropower into increasingly intelligent, distributed grids. Digital transformation, powered by AI, can enable accurate forecasting, predictive analytics, and IoT-driven self-healing grids, unlocking a sustainable future at scale.

Gartner projects that by 2027, over 50% of enterprise AI models will be industry-specific, up from about 1% in 2023. For utilities, this shift toward domain-tuned AI accelerates adoption in forecasting, asset performance, and customer operations. IDC’s Utilities predictions and Forrester’s Generative AI outlook similarly point to a pivot from pilot to production, with measured value in core operational use cases

AI Use Cases and SAP Utilities Solutions:

  • Advanced Renewable Forecasting: AI brings together historical generation, weather, and grid conditions to predict renewable output, enhance grid stability, and optimize dispatch. SAP enablers: SAP Energy Data Management (EDM), SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), SAP Datasphere for data fabric, and SAP S/4HANA Utilities for integration.
  • Intelligent Demand-Side Management: AI dynamically adjusts loads across sectors - smart appliances, EVs, industrial processes balancing supply and reducing peaks. SAP enablers: SAP Cloud for Utilities, SAP BRIM and SAP Subscription Billing for innovative tariffs, and SAC for optimization.
  • Proactive Predictive Maintenance: AI-driven anomaly detection improves asset reliability and avoids costly outages. SAP enablers: SAP Asset Performance Management (APM), SAP Asset Intelligence Network (AIN), SAP Field Service Management (FSM), and SAP S/4HANA Asset Management.

What are the opportunities of converging AI and SAP Solutions?

  • Reliability & Predictive Maintenance at Scale
    AI models fuse SCADA, asset history, and condition data to detect anomalies early, optimize spares, and move from time-based to condition-based maintenance - cutting SAIDI/SAIFI and truck rolls.

SAP enablers: SAP Asset Performance Management (APM), SAP Field Service Management (FSM), SAP S/4HANA Asset Management, SAP Asset Intelligence Network (AIN), and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) for predictive insights.

  • DER Orchestration, Flexibility & Market Settlement
    Forecasting and dispatching behind-the-meter solar, storage, EVs, and microgrids; forming virtual power plants (VPPs)  and optimizing participation in flexibility/ancillary markets.

SAP enablers: SAP Energy Data Management (EDM) for metering and settlement, SAP Billing and Revenue Innovation Management (BRIM) and SAP Subscription Billing for new tariffs and flexibility services, SAP S/4HANA Utilities for end-to-end customer-to-cash, and SAP Analytics Cloud for forecast optimization.

  • Customer & Prosumer Experience (CX) and Personalized Energy Services
    Hyper-personalized advisory, usage insights, TOU nudges, EV-smart-charging offers, and prosumer engagement that drive satisfaction and reduce churn.

SAP enablers: SAP S/4HANA Utilities, SAP BRIM for complex pricing/bundles, SAP Subscription Billing, SAP Customer Data Platform (CDP), SAP Service Cloud, and SAP Marketing Cloud for tailored engagement.

  • Sustainability, Emissions & “Green AI” Operations
    AI to optimize dispatch, reduce losses, and cut emissions; automated Scope 1–3 tracking and audit-ready reporting; and energy-efficient AI practices to minimize compute footprints.

SAP enablers: SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) for KPI governance, SAP Product Footprint Management (PFM) for footprint calculations, SAP Environment, Health, and Safety (EHS) for operational compliance, and SAP Signavio for process redesign.

  • Workforce Productivity, Safety & Knowledge Capture
    AI copilots for planners/dispatchers; mobile assistants for field technicians (procedures, PPE checks, hazards); automated close-outs and claims; and computer vision for safety observance.

SAP enablers: SAP Field Service Management (FSM) (mobile work), SAP Asset Performance Management (APM) (procedures & failure modes), SAP EHS (permits/safety), SAP Build Work Zone and SAP Enable Now for just-in-time guidance.

  • Revenue Innovation & Margin Protection
    AI-informed margin management (hedging, loss reduction), prosumer/VPP monetization, dynamic pricing, flexibility services, and performance-based programs.

SAP enablers: SAP BRIM, SAP Subscription Billing, SAP Profitability and Performance Management (PaPM), SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Datasphere (data fabric for scenario modeling).

Let's look at the challenges and practical mitigations

  • Data Foundations, Quality & Interoperability: Model performance hinges on clean, timely, connected data across OT (SCADA, AMI, APM) and IT (billing, CRM).

Mitigations with SAP: Establish a utility data fabric with SAP Datasphere; unify meter/market data via SAP EDM; standardize models in SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP); use SAP Integration Suite for OT/IT connectors; govern with SAP Master Data Governance (MDG).

  • AI Risk, Governance & Model Compliance (AI TRiSM/Responsible AI): Bias, drift, explainability, safety, and regulatory scrutiny (especially for GenAI and automated decisioning).

Mitigations with SAP: Use SAP BTP with SAP AI Core and AI Launchpad for lifecycle control; log lineage and approvals; embed human-in-the-loop; instrument KPIs in SAC; codify policies in Signavio.

  • Cybersecurity & Critical Infrastructure Protection: Expanded attack surface across DERs, edge devices, mobile crews, and market interfaces; GenAI introduces new vectors (prompt injection, data leakage).

Mitigations with SAP: Apply least-privilege and policy-based access on SAP BTP; integrate security analytics; segment OT/IT interfaces; harden APIs with SAP Integration Suite; capture end-to-end audit trails.

  • Compute, Energy Footprint & “Green AI”: Training/serving advanced models can inflate energy use, potentially conflicting with utility decarbonization goals.

Mitigations with SAP: Favor smaller, domain-tuned models hosted efficiently on SAP BTP; leverage inference optimization, demand-response scheduling of batch jobs, and carbon-aware routing; track emissions in SAP Sustainability Control Tower and Product Footprint Management.

  • Talent, Change & Operating Model: AI value stalls without product-centric teams, MLOps, and business ownership of outcomes.

Mitigations with SAP: Establish an AI value office; use SAP Signavio for process redesign; adopt MLOps on BTP/AI Launchpad; embed copilot-assisted work in SAP FSM and SAP S/4HANA.

  • Regulatory, Market & Ethical Constraints: Rate design, model explainability, and consumer data use are under tightening scrutiny.

Mitigations with SAP: Keep explainability artifacts for decisions (SAC narratives, model cards in AI Launchpad); enforce privacy-by-design with SAP CDP and consent management; maintain audit trails across EDM/BRIM/market processes.

Conclusion: 

AI is the cornerstone for clean energy transformation. By leveraging SAP’s intelligent utilities solutions and TCS’s innovation, utilities can boost efficiency, integrate renewables, and drive decarbonization. The path to a greener future lies in combining advanced technology with strategic energy management and robust governance. For CXOs, this means making informed, data-driven decisions, ensuring regulatory compliance, and creating sustainable value for customers and shareholders alike. Those who act decisively today will not only navigate the energy transition successfully but also set the benchmark for resilient, future-ready utilities.

entry.title: Basic Tips for Beginners in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) with BW Live
entry.content:
Beginner Tips for SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) with BW Live Connection

While working in SAC, I faced some common challenges. Here are the problems and how I solved them:

1. Story and Page Filters with BW Live Data

    • Problem: I was not sure whether SAC filters process locally or in BW.
    • Solution: Filters always trigger BW to recalculate and send back results. Only cosmetic changes (sort, format, hide columns) happen in SAC.

2. Scripting – Dynamic Input Handling

    • Problem: When using input fields, numbers were treated as text and gave wrong results in calculations.
    • Solution: Convert string to number:
    • var numberValue = ConvertUtils.stringToNumber(InputField_1.getValue());

3. Debugging Data in a Widget

    • Problem: I could not see what exactly my table widget was holding in the backend.
    • Solution: Use ResultSet in script:

              var resultset = Table_1.getDataSource().getResultSet();

              console.log(resultset);

This showed me all members and values in console.

4. Performance Issue with Dimensions

    • Problem: My story was very slow though I used only few attributes in the widget.
    • Solution: Reduced unnecessary attributes in the model → story became faster.

✅These are small but practical solutions that helped me when starting SAC development. I hope this helps other beginners too.

entry.title: Build a Data-Driven Enterprise with SAP’s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology
entry.content:
What is SAP BTP Guidance Framework: The Guidance Framework provides clear direction and a structured approach to adopting SAP technologies. With this guidance, you can develop intelligent applications using advanced analytics, equipping your organization with a robust foundation to support agile innovation. For more details read this blog. 

In this blog post, we will look into how to build a Data-Driven Enterprise with SAP’s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology under SAP BTP Guidance Framework. You can find this Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology pillar under SAP BTP Guidance Framework. 

It’s imperative that in today’s economy, data is more than just numbers—it’s the foundation of innovation, strategy, and growth backed by AI. Yet many organizations still struggle to unlock the full potential of their data and give it purpose. SAP’s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology under SAP BTP Guidance Framework offers a structured, four-phase approach that helps enterprises transform raw data into actionable insights while building a strong data-driven culture. 

The Four Phases of SAP’s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology 

1. Scoping & Baseline Analysis: In this phase you can set the foundation by: 

  • Defining the scope of investigation across business processes, organizational units, and data domains. 
  • Assessing current data architecture and capabilities. 
  • Identifying gaps, pain points, and opportunities for improvement. 

Benefit of this phase is that your business will have a clear baseline architecture, capability assessment, and prioritized opportunities. 

2. Business Outcomes & Solution Requirements: the focus in this phase shifts to aligning data with measurable business goals such as:  

  • Define specific, data-driven business outcomes. 
  • Analyze use cases that trace how raw data transforms into business value. 
  • Identify required data products and map end-to-end integration flows. 

This phase allows to clearly define business outcome definitions and solution context diagrams. 

 3. Capability Map & Solution Architecture: this phase transforms requirements into a target architecture by: 

  • Developing a capability map using SAP BTP Maturity Assessment 
  • Explore architecture options through traditional capability mapping or solution diagrams from the SAP Discovery Center. 
  • Validate the preferred architecture with proof-of-concepts. 

With this phase the target solution architecture is validated through capability mapping and pilots. 

 4. Data Governance & Roadmaps: this final phase ensures long-term sustainability: 

  • Conduct a maturity assessment for data governance and organizational roles. 
  • Define roles such as Chief Data Officer, Data Steward, and Governance Manager. 
  • Build a roadmap with clear clusters (e.g., implementation, operations, security). 

The key benefit of this phase is to define Data governance framework, organizational structure, and a roadmap for execution. 

What makes SAP’s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology stand out is that it’s not just about technology—it’s about data, people and processes. By integrating governance, roles, and organizational change management, it ensures that data initiatives aren’t just implemented but also adopted across the enterprise. For organizations aiming to thrive in a data-driven economy, SAP’s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology provides more than a roadmap—it delivers a proven framework for turning data into business value and give it purpose. By combining architecture best practices with governance and cultural adoption, it helps enterprises evolve from simply managing data to truly innovating with it. 

To read more about SAP’s Data & Analytics Advisory Methodology check out SAP Discovery Center. 

“Organizations that adopt this framework position themselves to lead in the AI-driven economy” 

Previous blogs in the series:

  • SAP BTP AI Best Practices: Your Ultimate Guide for Building AI Solutions
  • SAP Discovery Center Expands and Welcomes the SAP BTP Guidance Framework
  • SAP BTP Developer’s Guide: Essential Best Practices from Setup to Scale
  • Introducing SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4

Stay tuned for the next blog post in our ‘Exploring the SAP BTP Guidance Framework’ series! 
SAP Business Technology Platform SAP Business Data Cloud RISE with SAP SAP Business Suite Data Management

entry.title: Your Spreadsheet on Steroids: 6 Powerful New Features for the SAC Excel Add-in
entry.content:
For data analysts and planners, the debate between the flexibility of Microsoft Excel and the governed power of enterprise platforms like SAP Analytics Cloud is a familiar one. Excel offers unparalleled freedom for ad-hoc analysis, while SAC provides a single source of truth, robust security, and collaborative scale. This often creates a clunky workflow, forcing users to manually rebuild analyses as they move between environments.
Recent updates to the SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) add-in for Microsoft Excel are fundamentally changing this dynamic, bridging the gap between these two worlds in powerful and surprising ways. This post highlights four of the most impactful new features that are transforming the add-in from a simple data connector into an indispensable tool for serious analysis and planning.
1. From Polished Story to Powerful Spreadsheet in a Single Click
A significant update in the Q3 / 2025.17 release introduces the ability to transfer a table directly from an SAP Analytics Cloud story into Excel. This isn't just a static copy-paste of values; the transferred table is fully functional within the add-in. It retains the same data source, navigation state (including all dimensions, measures, rows, and columns), filters, and variables that were configured in the story.
This creates an immediate, frictionless pivot from a high-level presentation in a Story to a granular, what-if analysis in Excel. Analysts can now investigate an anomaly they spot in a dashboard without losing a moment of momentum or context rebuilding the query.
Note: You need to migrate your table to the New table experience available from 2025 QRC3 release. The option to open the story in a Excel Add-in needs to be enabled in Table properties in the Builder Panel.

This enables Open in Excel Add-in option in Table.

 Eureka, Story opens in Excel with structure and calculations migrated.

 

2. Your Data Now Has a Voice: In-Cell Conversations Arrive
The 2025.15 release brings collaboration directly to your data cells with the introduction of data point comments. Users can now view and create comments on specific data cells within their Excel tables. Critically, these comments are fully synchronized with SAP Analytics Cloud, meaning a comment added in Excel is immediately visible in the web application, and vice versa.
To make this even more powerful, the SAP.GETDATACOMMENT formula (introduced in version 2025.17) allows you to retrieve these comments programmatically. If multiple comments exist for a data point, the formula returns the last comment of the thread. This development marks a shift from static reporting to true collaborative analysis. The addition of the SAP.GETDATACOMMENT formula elevates these comments from simple annotations to query able metadata. This unlocks the ability to build exception reports, dashboards, or even KPIs based on the presence and content of commentary, creating a powerful new layer of qualitative analysis.
 
Enable data point comments from the Table Option in Designer Panel

This will enable a comment widget to add comments

The comments are in sync and can be viewed in web stories also and vice versa.

3. Enterprise-Grade Guardrails for Your Planning Spreadsheets

 

For organizations using the add-in for financial planning, the 2025.17 release delivers a crucial governance enhancement. Data Access Controls (DCS) and Validation Rules that are defined in the central SAP Analytics Cloud model are now automatically applied and visualized directly within the Excel add-in.
This is a critical update because it de-risks the use of Excel for enterprise planning. It allows finance teams to leverage the full flexibility of their preferred tool while ensuring that every input automatically inherits the security, data integrity rules, and governance defined in the central SAC model. The "Wild West" spreadsheet is officially tamed.
 
4. A Faster, More Intuitive Way to Build Your Analysis
A pair of recent user experience enhancements have combined to make the process of building and modifying analyses significantly faster and more intuitive. First, version 2025.13 introduced a resizable builder panel that features a permanent pane listing all available dimensions and measures. This allows for easy browsing and searching of the data source objects.
Building on that foundation, version 2025.19 added drag-and-drop functionality. Users can now simply drag objects from the permanent list and drop them into the desired pane (e.g., rows or columns) to build out their table. These  updates work together to reduce clicks and streamline the entire analysis design process, letting users get to insights more quickly.
 

5. Make your sheets colorful

Now you can add styling and thresholds to your Excel tables. This helps applying corporate colors or creating a more visual appealing layouts.

You can use a list of SAC predefined cell styles or create custom cell styles by duplicating and existing cell styles.

You can choose the styling as well as the area of the table layout where it should be applied.

6. Create Calculated Measure ( Episode 1 : Restricted Measure support)

The long awaited feature of the ability to create calculated measures for your business calculation is now available also in Excel. As a first feature set, only restricted measures are supported. The steps are very similar to how we define calculations in web story. Currently only value based restrictions are supported ( both dimension and attributes). No support for dynamic restrictions for date dimensions like Current Period, prior Period etc. readily available in web stories. Never the less its a good start and I wish to see the remaining features soon. Both restricted accounts and restricted measures are supported.

Already defined Calculations can also be edited if required.

 

Conclusion: A Final Thought
The SAP Analytics Cloud add-in for Excel is rapidly evolving. It's moving beyond its origins as a simple data connector to become a fully-featured, collaborative, and secure extension of the core platform. By bringing enterprise governance and modern collaboration features into the familiar grid of a spreadsheet, it offers a powerful new paradigm for analysis and planning.
With these new capabilities fusing the best of Excel and the cloud, what established workflow are you now ready to rethink?
 
Thanks for reading. I hope you enjoyed the blog.

Check the SAP Analytics Cloud topic page for more up to date information https://community.sap.com/topics/cloud-analytics

follow and read other informative blog posts on SAC browse the below link

https://blogs.sap.com/tags/67838200100800006884/

 

Regards

Nikhil

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud - From Provisioning to Intelligent Applications
entry.content:
Introduction to SAP Business Data Cloud

In this blog, we will try to go over the Introduction to SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) and then the Components and Building Blocks of SAP BDC.

SAP BDC is a fully managed software-as-a-service (SaaS) offering from SAP designed to address this need of managing vast volumes of data originating from diverse systems. It consolidates and governs all SAP data while seamlessly integrating third-party sources, delivering contextualized, trusted data to business leaders for more impactful decision-making. By harmonizing mission-critical data into a unified semantic layer, the platform eliminates the overhead of data extraction and replication.  Supporting a wide range of use cases across industries and business functions, SAP BDC ensures that data is consistently accessible, secure, and ready for advanced analytics.

Key Aspects of SAP Business Data Cloud

  • Intelligent Applications: AI-driven apps that leverage your data and business context to automate processes, adapt dynamically, and drive transformative outcomes in real time.
  • Data Products: Prebuilt, customizable, and governed data assets that come enriched with business semantics, documentation, and APIs—accelerating deployment across a wide range of use cases.
  • Business Data Fabric: A comprehensive data and analytics foundation that integrates SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, modernized SAP Business Warehouse, data engineering capabilities, and AI/ML innovations through SAP Databricks.
  • AI-Enriched Decision Making: Enterprise-grade tools that deliver responsible, context-aware AI for reporting and analytics —empowering smarter, faster decisions.

Components of SAP Business Data Cloud

Source Systems:  SAP BDC connects seamlessly to various source systems—such as SAP S/4HANA—to identify and extract key business data entities. These include tables, views, and other structures that contain mission-critical data across domains like HR, finance, supply chain. By integrating with these systems, SAP BDC ensures that foundational business data is readily available for analytics, governance, and intelligent application development.

Foundational Services in SAP Business Data Cloud: Within SAP BDC, data extracted from source systems flows into the Foundation Services layer. This foundational component is responsible for ingesting, integrating, cleansing, and harmonizing both structured and unstructured data. It ensures that the data is properly aligned and enriched as part of SAP-managed Data Products, forming the backbone of trusted, analytics-ready information across the SAP BDC landscape.

SAP Datasphere: SAP Datasphere serves as the modeling and governance layer atop the BDC Semantic Layer. It provides a robust set of tools for designing analytical data models, defining business logic, managing data lineage, enforcing governance and security. In addition to its core modeling capabilities, SAP Datasphere supports machine learning and AI extensions, making it a foundational component for advanced analytics and intelligent decision-making. Datasphere acts as the data engine behind SAP Analytics Cloud, feeding it with both prebuilt and custom insights for reporting and visualization. It also enables customers to create custom data products using the SAP Datasphere Object Store, which supports zero-copy data access via the Delta Sharing Protocol - ensuring efficient, secure, and scalable data sharing across the enterprise.

SAP Databricks: SAP Databricks is a specialized integration of the Databricks platform embedded directly within SAP BDC. It combines industry-leading capabilities in AI, machine learning, data science, and data engineering with semantically rich, business-ready data from SAP applications. This component significantly enhances analytics by enabling generative AI scenarios—without the need for complex data pipelines. Through zero-copy Delta Sharing, SAP Databricks connects directly to SAP Data Products, allowing seamless access and enrichment of data without replication. By bridging enterprise-grade SAP data with the flexibility of Databricks, organizations can accelerate innovation, streamline operations, and unlock deeper insights across their business landscape.

SAP Analytics Cloud: SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) empowers business analytics by directly consuming integrated data from the SAP Datasphere component within BDC. It supports rich visualization, reporting, and AI-driven analytics across the enterprise—all within a unified, cloud-based SaaS environment. By leveraging semantically aligned data from Datasphere, SAC enables organizations to generate actionable insights, build dynamic dashboards, and drive informed decision-making at scale.

SAP BW and SAP BW/4HANA Integration: To support legacy compatibility, SAP BW and SAP BW/4HANA objects can be technically onboarded into SAP BDC. This integration enables organizations to migrate data and maintain hybrid use cases—bridging traditional data warehousing with modern cloud-based analytics—until the official end-of-support timeline for BW systems. By incorporating BW artifacts into BDC, businesses can preserve existing investments while gradually transitioning to a unified, governed, and AI-ready data landscape.

Building Blocks of SAP Business Data Cloud

Provisioning an SAP Business Data Cloud Tenant

An SAP BDC tenant is provisioned via the SAP for Me portal using a guided, self-service workflow. This process enables organizations to activate and configure the components of SAP Business Data Cloud according to their commercial entitlements. The provisioning journey begins with the BDC Core Component or Cockpit, which serves as the central management interface for the entire SAP BDC landscape. 

Once the BDC cockpit is provisioned, the next step is to provision (from SAP for Me) the core capabilities and applications, including: SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Databricks.

After these systems are successfully provisioned through SAP for Me, users can  begin creating Formations—structured configurations that define how data products and applications are orchestrated across the landscape.

Formation in SAP Business Data Cloud

A Formation in SAP Business Data Cloud is a logical grouping of SAP systems and related components designed to support specific business scenarios or integration use cases. Formations simplify connectivity and provide a unified view of all systems, making it easier to manage integrations, extensions, and orchestrate data across the SAP BDC landscape.  Formations are created by selecting the required SAP systems—these must first be provisioned via the SAP for Me portal. Once provisioned, they appear in the Systems tab of the portal and can be included in one or more formations. Each formation can consist of multiple systems such as SAP BDC Core, SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP BW, SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Databricks. These systems are synchronized within the formation to enable streamlined operations and cohesive business processes. Multiple formations can be created to support extended or complex business scenarios.

Benefits of Using Formations

  • Simplified Integration: Centralizes the grouping and management of systems required for a business scenario.
  • Scalability and Flexibility: Easily add or remove systems as organizational needs evolve.
  • Governance and Control: Enables centralized configuration and oversight, improving compliance and reducing maintenance overhead.

SAP Data Products in Business Data Cloud 

An SAP Data Product is a curated and refined dataset derived from data ingested from SAP solutions. It encompasses a Business Data Set that includes master data, transactional records, analytics datasets, and configuration data—all semantically aligned to ensure consistency and usability.

These datasets are enriched with meaningful metadata and documentation, making them easily consumable and understandable. Within the SAP BDC, Data Products serve as the core building blocks for Intelligent Applications, enabling advanced analytics and decision-making.  SAP delivers and manages these Data Products as part of its SaaS offering, maintaining full lifecycle ownership. However, customers can customize them to suit specific business needs. Each Data Product includes all necessary artifacts—such as CDS views, connectors, flows, jobs, and lifecycle management tools—required to support its associated use cases within SAP BDC. They are easily discoverable through the SAP BDC product catalog. These products are designed by line-of-business experts to help organizations maximize the value of their data. Types of Data Products

  • Primary Data Products: Directly sourced from applications, representing original data from systems like SAP S/4HANA. They are not derived from other data products.
  • Derived Data Products: Built by SAP using existing datasets or APIs. This offer added value by combining or transforming data from multiple sources.

Custom or Customer Managed Data Products : SAP BDC also supports custom data products, which can be curated within SAP Datasphere. These leverage the Datasphere Object Store and Delta Sharing Protocol, enabling zero-copy data access for efficient and secure data sharing.

Intelligent Applications in SAP Business Data Cloud

Intelligent Applications are AI-driven, visualization-centric solutions designed to address specific business scenarios. Unlike general-purpose analytics tools, these applications are built with SAP-managed analytical assets and functionalities that deliver value through process, domain, or analytical intelligence. They typically include data products, semantic models, and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) stories. These applications foster collaboration between analytics and data science teams by providing ready-made dashboards enriched with AI-generated insights. Their embedded business logic and contextual data models eliminate the need for organizations to build complex analytical frameworks from scratch—saving time and resources. The core structure of Intelligent Applications includes:

  • SAC Stories: Serve as the front-end interface, offering rich visualizations tailored to specific analytics use cases.
  • SAP Datasphere Models and Views: Includes the backend logic and data orchestration.
  • Semantic Models and Story Templates: Combined to deliver reusable, customizable dashboards.

These applications are cataloged within the SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC), making them easy to discover, deploy, and extend.

Installation and Customization

To explore and install Intelligent Applications:

  1. Log in to the SAP BDC Cockpit. Browse the available applications and their documentation.
  2. Upon installation, a suite of artifacts is deployed across SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud, including Data Products, Replication Flows, Tables and Views, Analytic Models, Roles and Dashboards.

 Customization Guidelines

  • SAP-managed applications and their dependencies are read-only, but users can copy and adapt components.
  • SAC Stories can be duplicated and tailored to meet specific business needs.
  • For advanced scenarios, users may replicate and modify the underlying analytic models ( within SAP Datasphere).
  • Changes to models will affect both the original and copied stories, so version control and impact analysis are recommended.

Key Differentiation between Business Content and Intelligent Applications

  • Business Content provides a set of pre-built models and other artifacts, but customers manage the implementation, configuration and maintenance of these solutions.
  • Intelligent Applications are fully managed and curated by SAP and delivered as software-as-a-service designed to cater specific business use cases or scenarios.

Hope this helps you understand the basics and get started on SAP Business Data Cloud.

entry.title: Planning & Analytics (P&A) is an essential part of SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC)
entry.content:
In today’s fast-paced business world, the ability to effectively steer and lead an organisation is crucial for achieving strategic goals and maintaining a competitive edge. The capacity to fully harness and derive value from organisational data is key success criteria. However, many companies struggle with data problems (fragmented information, outdated systems, and the challenge of preparing data for emerging technologies like AI).

Our blog series will provide valuable insights for decision-makers seeking to harness SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to enhance operational efficiency, optimise resource allocation, and achieve long-term objectives. By featuring detailed planning & analytics topics, the series will illustrate the transformative impact of SAP BDC in addressing the operational complexities of today’s business environment. The second blog post will summarise key arguments why Planning & Analytics (P&A) is an integral part of SAP BDC.

Picture 1: SAP BDC Intelligent Application - Working CapitalThere are several blog posts in the series that will cover advantages of SAP BDC in the context of business steering, so please stay tuned for the upcoming blogs:

  1. The value of SAP BDC in the context of business steering
  2. Planning & Analytics is an essential part of SAP BDC (THIS BLOG POST)
  3. Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC
  4. Is AI going to “retire” a dashboard?
  5. Simulations, a game changer in today’s volatile world
  6. Extend existing planning scenarios of SAP BPC/BW-IP in SAP BDC
  7. Real-time steering with LIVE planning
  8. SAP PaPM - The role of business calculation engine in business steering
  9. Self – service analytics and real time business steering
  10. Business steering powered by AI agents
  11. Leverage data products in the context of planning & forecasting
  12. Introducing AI/ML capabilities by SAP Databricks

SAP BDC is equipped with powerful data management, planning & analytics (P&A), and innovative AI capabilities to tackle all these challenges and P&A is an essential part of SAP BDC. It provides transformative insights, seamless integration, AI augmentation, and enhanced data quality. These capabilities are crucial for effective business decision-making and strategic planning. Here are the key reasons why P&A is vital within SAP BDC:

Picture 2: SAP BDC high level architecture & flows in the context of business steering

  • Transformative Insights: P&A uncovers hidden insights using advanced analytics and planning applications across all lines of business. This capability allows organisations to make informed decisions based on comprehensive data analysis.
  • Seamless Integration: It combines SAP and third-party data to unify diverse data sources, enabling comprehensive analysis and a holistic view of business operations. This integration is crucial for maintaining data consistency and accuracy across the enterprise.
  • AI Augmentation: The integration of business AI, such as SAP’s AI copilot Joule, enhances decision-making by providing augmented insights and predictive capabilities. This helps businesses anticipate future trends and make proactive decisions.
  • Enhanced Data Quality: P&A automatically connects data across the business, ensuring accuracy and accelerating time to insight. This is essential for maintaining high data quality and reliability in business processes.
  • Agile Modelling and Predictive Analysis: Planning & Analytics supports agile data modelling aligned with analytics. It uses AI and machine learning to facilitate predictive analysis and simulation, enabling businesses to adapt quickly to changing conditions and optimise their strategies.
  • End-to-End Visibility: Planning & Analytics offers a 360-degree view of critical business processes with fully-managed, curated data products. This comprehensive visibility and control over operations provide businesses with a clear understanding of their performance.

Picture 3: SAP BDC - AI-powered Live-Planning & Analytics in SAP BDC

Planning & Analytics is an essential part of SAP BDC, empowering organisations with the tools and insights needed to drive strategic initiatives, improve efficiency, and enhance decision-making across the enterprise.

The usage of Planning & Analytics (P&A) is therefore closely connected to the performance of an organisation and creation of business value through several key mechanisms that enhance decision-making, efficiency, and strategic alignment. Here’s how P&A impacts organisational performance:

  • Real-Time Insights: The ability to access real-time data and insights allows organisations to respond quickly to market changes and operational challenges. This agility is crucial for maintaining competitive advantage and optimising performance, especially in turbulent times like today.
  • Strategic Alignment: By aligning financial and operational plans with strategic objectives, P&A ensures that all parts of the organisation are working towards common goals. This alignment is critical for achieving long-term success and improving overall performance.
  • Data-Driven Decision Making: P&A tools provide a single source of truth for data, reducing the need for manual reconciliation and enabling more accurate and timely decision-making. This shift from manual processes to automated data integration enhances efficiency and reduces errors.
  • Improved Forecasting Accuracy: P&A tools, such as SAP Analytics Cloud, enable organisations to conduct predictive forecasting and scenario planning. This improves the accuracy of financial and operational forecasts, providing a forward-looking view of performance. This allows leaders to react promptly, leading to better resource allocation, strategic planning, and improved performance.
  • Enhanced Collaboration: By integrating planning processes across different departments, such as HR and finance, P&A fosters collaboration and alignment within the organisation. This integration helps create a unified approach to achieving business goals and improves communication across teams.
  • Increased Efficiency: Automation of planning processes reduces the time and effort required for data collection and analysis, allowing employees to focus on higher-value tasks such as strategic analysis and decision-making.

In summary, Planning & Analytics enhances organisational performance by improving forecasting accuracy, fostering collaboration, providing real-time insights, enabling data-driven forward looking decision-making, ensuring strategic alignment, and increasing efficiency. These benefits collectively contribute to a more agile, informed, and strategically aligned organisation.

Do you want to embark on a journey? Please reach out to your SAP representative and register for your SAP BDC Discovery Workshop!

In our next blog post, @Nektarios_Vasileiou33  will take you behind the scenes to unbox the key Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC — solutions that help businesses streamline planning, enhance decision-making, and foster cross-department collaboration. By exploring SAP BDC capabilities, you’ll see how they drive more effective enterprise planning and analysis. Get ready for insights that unlock sharper strategies and smarter decisions. Stay tuned!

entry.title: SAML SSO configuration in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)
entry.content:
How to Configure SAML on SAP Analytics Cloud Tenant Using IAS as a Custom IDP

With SAML 2.0 Single Sign-On (SSO), you can simplify authentication for your SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) users while improving security and reducing password fatigue. By integrating SAC with SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS) (or any other identity provider) as a custom Identity Provider (IdP), you gain centralized control over user access and streamline the login experience.

In this guide, we’ll walk through the process of setting up SAML-based SSO step-by-step — from prerequisites to verification — ensuring a smooth configuration process for administrators.

What You’ll Learn

This guide is divided into three main sections:

  1. Prerequisites – Everything you need to prepare before starting the configuration.

  2. Step-by-Step Configuration – Detailed steps to set up SAML SSO between SAC and IAS.

  3. Verification and Go-Live – How to verify and finalize your configuration.

  4. Troubleshooting – Common issues, tips, and SAP Knowledge Base Articles (KBAs) to help you quickly resolve errors during or after setup.

By the end, you’ll have a fully functional SAML-based authentication setup, ready for production.

 

Configuring SAML SSO with IAS

Follow these steps carefully to configure SAML authentication for your SAC tenant.

Before you begin, make sure the following requirements are met. Prerequisites for SAC configuration:

  1. You must have an IdP that supports SAML 2.0 protocol.
  2. You must be able to configure your IdP.
  3. You must be assigned to the System Owner role in SAP Analytics Cloud. For more information, see Standard Application Roles.
  4. SAP Analytics Cloud can be hosted either on SAP data centers or on non-SAP data centers. Determine which environment SAP Analytics Cloud is hosted in by inspecting your SAP Analytics Cloud URL:
    • A single-digit number, for example us1 or jp1, indicates an SAP data center.
    • A two-digit number, for example eu10 or us30, indicates a non-SAP data center.
  5. If your users are connecting from Apple devices using the SAP Analytics Cloud mobile app, the certificate used by your IdP must be compatible with Apple's App Transport Security (ATS) feature.

Follow help page to enable SAML SSO : Enable a Custom SAML Identity Provider (Legacy Custom IdP)

Configuration steps:

1. Login to SAP Analytics Cloud tenant as System Owner with Default IDP.

2. Navigate to “System -> Administration”.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

3. From “Administration” tab switch to “Security” page, click on Edit button on the right corner and switch to SAML Single Sign-on SSO from SAP Cloud Identity (default).

4. Download metadata file mentioned under Step 1 “Download Service Provider metadata” in SAC and save it to your local machine.

5. Upload the SAP Analytics Cloud metadata file to your SAML IdP.

To complete this step, you will need to login to Cloud Identity Provisioning Services (IAS) and navigate to the following path “Applications & Resources -> Application -> Select your IAS application -> SAML 2.0 Configuration”. Under “Define from Metadata” section click on Browse and upload the metadata file which was downloaded from SAC in step 3 above.

6.  Map your SAML IdP user attributes and roles. 

After SAC metadata has been uploaded into IAS, navigate to “Applications & Resources -> Application -> Select your IAS application -> Attributes”  and configure SAML mapping as it is defined in step 7 in help page  Enable a Custom SAML Identity Provider.

Important! - For SAML attributes to be recognized it is also important that the “Groups” attribute contains the value of “sac''

7. In IAS, navigate to Tenant Settings tab under ''Application & Resources.''

Under Single Sign-on section, click on SAML 2.0 Configuration tab, and download metadata file from there.

Switch back to SAC tenant and continue Step 2 “Upload Identity Provider metadata”, upload the metadata file there.

8. Now we need to define User Attribute in Step 3 “Choose a user attribute to map to your identity provider” in SAC. It should map to User ID, Email, or a custom attribute. You can view your SAP Analytics Cloud user attributes in Security Users.

The attribute will be used to map users from your Custom IDP (in this case IAS)  to SAP Analytics Cloud. The user attribute you select must match the NameID (Subject Name Identifier) used in your custom SAML assertion.

In IAS tenant navigate to “Applications & Resources -> Application -> Select your IAS application -> Subject Name Identifier” and select same User Attribute for  “Select a basic attribute”, which was defined in SAP Analytics Cloud.

9. In Step 4, enter <Your Unique Identifier>. This value must identify the SAP Analytics Cloud system owner. The Login Credential provided here will be automatically set for your user.

Which means if attribute is set to email in step 3, then System Owner’s email should be defined in step 4 as per screenshot below.

10. After above steps have been completed, click on “Verify Account”. You can copy the URL by selecting  (Copy).

Please Note that: You must use a private session (Incognito) to log onto the URL; for example, Guest mode in Chrome. This ensures that when you log on to the dialog and select SAP Analytics Cloud, you are prompted to log in and do not reuse an existing browser session.

11. In the Verify Your Account dialog, select Check Verification. If the verification was successful, a green border should appear around the Login Credential box.

12. After verification was successful, click on save and conversion to SAML SSO should be completed.

By following all these steps, we have successfully configured SAML SSO on SAP Analytics Cloud tenant.

 

What is Identity Provider Administration Tool? 

The Identity Provider Administration tool allows system owners to manage the custom identity provider configured with SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC). Through the tool, the system owner can choose to upload new metadata for the current custom identity provider or revert to using the default identity provider.

You can read more about this tool here: Access the Identity Provider Administration Tool

How to access/use Identity Provider Administration Tool?

In the following, we’ll use Identity Provider Administration tool can be used to update metadata from custom IDP and how to revert SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) tenant back to default IDP.

Pre-requisites:

  • SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) must already be configured to use a custom identity provider.
  • You must be the system owner.

Procedure

  1. Log in with an S-user that has the same email address as the system owner of your system. If you don't yet have such an S-user, you can click the “Register” button and create a S-user. If you create a new S-user, you'll receive an email with an activation link that will let you set your password.

  2. Access the Identity Provider Administration tool using the following URL pattern:

    https://console.<data center>.sapanalytics.cloud/idp-admin/

    For example, if your SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) system is on eu10, then the URL is:

    https://console.eu10.sapanalytics.cloud/idp-admin/

    If your SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) system is on cn1, then the URL is:

    https://console.cn1.sapanalyticscloud.cn/idp-admin/

    If your tenant is on EUDP:

    https://console-eudp.eu1.sapanalytics.cloud/idp-admin/

    https://console-eudp.eu2.sapanalytics.cloud/idp-admin/

  3. Once you're logged in, you'll see a list of SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)systems for which you are the system owner.

  4. Select the system you want to work on by clicking on its row.

Once you're in the settings page for your system, you can see information about your current custom identity provider. If you need to reacquire your system's metadata, you can click the “Service Provider Metadata Download”. 

  1. If you don't want to manage your custom identity provider through Identity Provider Administration, you can disconnect your system by clicking “Disconnect IdP Admin from your system”.

  2. To proceed with either reverting to the default identity provider or updating the current custom identity provider, select the corresponding radio button and then click “Step 2”.
  3. (Optional) Revert to the default identity provider.

  4. Choose this option if you're having problems logging in with your custom identity provider and would like to revert to the default identity provider. Once the reversion has finished, you can exit the Identity Provider Administration tool and log in to your SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) to reconfigure your custom identity provider.

  5. Select the “Revert to default IdP” radio button to revert to the default IdP. 
    • Select “Yes” in the confirmation dialog to revert your authentication method back to the default IdP.   
    • Click “Step 3” to proceed to the validation step.   

       
  6. To re-upload the metadata file, use “Update IdP Metadata” button.
  7. On step 2, when prompted, browse for new metadata file and re-upload it.

Relevant KBA:

  • 2908073 - How to use the IdP Admin Tool to make changes to IdP Configuration in SAP Analytics Cloud when no access is available to the tenant 
  • 2975954 - Implement multiple Identity Providers (IdP) in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

Troubleshooting

If there is any issue/error that comes up when trying to login or when configuring SAML/SSO within SAC, please make sure following is configured correctly.

  • Correct Metadata is uploaded within SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) from custom IDP
  • Certificate is not expired within Metadata.
  • Correct “NameID” is passed from Custom IDP to SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)
  • If email is used as NameID, make sure the case matches between custom IDP and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)
  • If User ID is used as NameID, make sure it’s all in Capitals
  • During configuring SAML within SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) make sure to run verifying URL within INCOGNITO Browser window.

Example: After configuring SAML within SAC Users are not able to login and are getting errors: 

To debug the above error message, please do the steps below:

  1. Collect SAML traces as per KB 2461862 - Collecting SAML traces with Chrome, Edge or Firefox
  2. Open SAML Trace file (.json) within SAML Tracer tool, using “Import” button
  3. Once opened look for calls with SAML Tags
  4. Select “POST” call with SAML Tag and make sure all the required attributes are passed and in correct format. Pay attention to “NameID” and that it’s in correct format. 
  5. In the above example trace you can see that there is no “Groups” attribute is passed and therefore User is not able to login.

Another point which can be checked is the following:

1. To ensure the NameID attributes are matching between the 2 applications you may use the following URL:

https://<system-name>.authentication.<landscape>.hana.ondemand.com/config?action=who&details=true

2. Run the URL in an incognito browser session. It should redirect to the logon page of the Custom IdP (in this case, IAS) linked to the SAC tenant. After successful logon via the IdP credentials, look for UserName and ExternalId fields.

  • ExternalId - The value that the IdP forwards towards SAC as Subject Name Identifier (Name ID)
  • UserName - The value that is actually being compared to the SAC SAML attribute. This is due to one of the HANA services caching the value of ExternalID and storing it as UserName for faster authentication.

3. If UserName is not matching the SAC SAML attribute - authentication should fail.

NameID should be changed to ensure match between the 2 applications. If userName and SAC SAML attribute is matching - authentication should be successful

 

Conclusion

Integrating SAP Analytics Cloud with SAP Identity Authentication Service using SAML SSO brings a host of benefits:

  • Centralized authentication management across systems.

  • Enhanced security through standardized protocols.

  • Improved user experience with seamless, passwordless access.

By following this step-by-step guide, you’ve successfully configured a robust and secure SAML connection between SAC and IAS. Your users can now enjoy a simplified login experience, while you maintain full control over authentication and role management.

Relevant KBAs:

  • 2487567 - Troubleshooting SAML assertions when configuring SAML SSO in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)
  • 2922448 - SAML Attribute Mapping in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) & SAP Digital Boardroom Master KBA
  • 2908073 - How to use the IdP Admin Tool to make changes to IdP Configuration in SAP Analytics Cloud when no access is available to the tenant
  • 2879161 - How to update the SAML IdP Signing Certificate or Metadata.xml in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

entry.title: Unsupported Features with SAP Datasphere Live Connections in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Hello Cloud folks,

I would like to share some of the information that i searched for..

I faced lot of question after implementing SAC Stories on Live connection and this article helps to them.

when working with an SAC live connection to SAP Datasphere, you experience certain product limitations in SAC

In general, any SAP Datasphere system can be connected to any SAC system via the SAP Datasphere live connection in SAC.
Live connections between SAC and SAP Datasphere can be established across tenants . When using the SAC


– Datasphere live connection, We can build SAC stories or analytical applications that, at the same time, use data from a SAP
Datasphere space, multiple SAP Datasphere spaces, multiple SAP Datasphere spaces in multiple SAP Dataspheres as well as
any additional data sources that you have connected to SAC

When using the SAC – Datasphere live connection, SAC currently has the following product limitations:

Below are the list of  features that are not supported 

Analytics : 
Custom Shapes for Geo Maps are not supported
Version based variance features are not supported on SAP Datasphere data.
Version Mapping is not supported for SAP Datasphere data.
Blending is not supported.
Scheduling a Publication is not supported on SAP Datasphere data.
Linked Dimension is only supported for SAP Datasphere models from the same Space. It is not supported across Spaces.
R-Visualizations are not supported. Note: you can vote for this enhancement request here.
Comment Widgets are not supported
Copy Widgets between stories is not supported
Import Pages from Stories that contain Datasphere models is not supported

JustAsk : 
On-the-fly search with Datasphere models is supported.
Indexing Datasphere models in SAC JustAsk is not supported.
Open in Data Analyzer is not supported
Copy widget to Story is not supported
Stories in Classic Experience
Blending is supported for the following scenarios
SAP Datasphere data with local SAC data
SAP Datasphere data with SAP Datasphere data from the same Datasphere space.
Blending information across Datasphere spaces, or across Datasphere tenants, or blending of Datasphere data with
other Live Connections is not supported.
Using Hyperlinks with the option "Apply selected dimension as filter" enabled across Stories using SAP Datasphere Live
Connections is not supported.
SAP Datasphere Analytic models are not supported

SAP Datasphere Data Types
The following SAP Datasphere Data types are currently not supported in SAP Analytics Cloud:
Bigint
Binary
hana.binary
Large Binary
Large String


Planning
SAC Planning data can now be stored in Datasphere with seamless planning However, planning
still requires the import of data into the SAC model and is not based on the SAP Datasphere live connection 


Smart features
Smart Insights are not supported on SAP Datasphere data. .
Smart Discovery is not supported on SAP Datasphere data.
Smart Predict is not supported on SAP Datasphere data.
SAP Digital Boardroom
Stories built on top of SAP Datasphere live data are not supported in SAP Digital Boardroom.

Regards,

Kartheek Kota

Reference:

https://me.sap.com/notes/2832606

entry.title: Optimizing SAP Analytics Cloud – Best Practices and Performance
entry.content:
SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) offers powerful capabilities for planning, analytics, and business intelligence—all in one unified platform. But to truly unlock its potential, it's essential to follow best practices that ensure optimal performance, scalability, and maintainability. In this blog, we’ll explore some of the insights and recommendations across four key pillars of SAC:

  • Analytics & Planning Modeling: Structuring your models for flexibility, performance, and future growth.
  • Calculations: Designing efficient formulas and leveraging SAC’s calculation engine wisely.
  • Data Actions: Automating planning workflows with precision and minimal overhead.
  • Story Building: Crafting intuitive, responsive, and insightful dashboards that drive decision-making.

Performance Considerations

Performance in SAC isn’t a post-implementation concern—it must be a core priority from the very beginning of your project. Striking the right balance between rich functionality and responsive performance is essential. While functional requirements drive business value, they must be matched by a system that performs reliably and efficiently. Performance optimization touches every layer of your SAC solution: from backend data architecture and model design to story layout, user concurrency, and even device and network configurations.

Model Design

  • Model Scope: Clearly define the model’s scope, type (planning or analytics), required metrics, and data granularity based on business objectives. This clarity prevents over engineering and ensures alignment with user needs.
  • Reusability: Build modular models that can be reused across multiple stories and planning scenarios. Reusability reduces duplication, simplifies maintenance, and accelerates development cycles.
  • Lean Model Structure: Key performance drivers include the number of measures, dimensions, hierarchies, and members per dimension. Reducing unnecessary dimensions and avoiding overly complex hierarchies directly improves query performance and system responsiveness. Focus on dimensions that are essential for data collection. Attributes such as geographic area or gender can often be derived rather than modeled as standalone dimensions. Evaluate whether static dimensions can be converted into attributes, and consider splitting large models into smaller, purpose-driven ones. Simpler models are easier to maintain, faster to calculate, and more memory efficient. Avoid adding dimensions or calculations unless they deliver clear business value.
  • Understanding Model Types: From a performance perspective, Analytic Models connected to live data sources place minimal demand on SAC infrastructure, as most of the processing load is handled by the source system itself. In contrast, Analytic Models using acquired data rely on the embedded HANA database, primarily for read operations. While this does introduce some system load, it tends to be moderate and more CPU-intensive than memory-intensive. Planning Models with acquired data, however, offer richer functionality but come with higher resource requirements—impacting both CPU and memory. Their performance is heavily influenced by model design factors such as the number of exception aggregations, the complexity and volume of dimensions, and the breadth of the user’s security context during data entry operations.
  • Additional performance-critical factors include the number of concurrent users, the volume and structure of the data, and the frequency and complexity of scheduled jobs or data actions also play a significant role in determining system responsiveness and scalability.
  • Use Measure Based Model: When designing models in SAC, opting for a Measure-Based Model is highly recommended due to its significant advantages in performance, calculation flexibility, and overall modeling efficiency.
    • Enhanced Performance & Scalability: Measure-based models are optimized for faster processing and reduced complexity, especially in large-scale planning scenarios.
    • Flexible Structure: These models support both accounts and measures, with the account dimension now optional giving you greater design freedom.
    • Reusable Calculations: You can define base measure calculations that simplify logic reuse across stories and planning workflows.
    • Advanced Aggregation: Measures can be aggregated more efficiently, improving responsiveness and reducing load times.
    • Expanded Data Type Support: Measure-based models accommodate a wider range of data types, enhancing versatility.
    • Multi-Currency Planning: With base currency measures, currency conversion becomes seamless, enabling planning across multiple currencies with ease.

Dimension Design

  • Leverage Public Dimensions: Use the Public Dimension feature to manage master data independently, allowing for centralized updates and reuse across models. Avoid importing all source system tables—focus only on dimensions relevant to data entry and planning.
  • Dimension hierarchies and members: Deep hierarchies can be resource intensive. Limit the number of levels to reduce complexity and improve query performance. Keep the number of members in each dimension—including the Account dimension—lean. Import only valid members and apply filters to exclude irrelevant data.
  • Date Dimension: Use SAC’s standard date dimension with SAP-managed hierarchies (Year–Quarter–Month–Day) to minimize performance impact.

Planning Area

  • The planning area defines the specific slice of data within a model that end users can interact with—whether through stories or data actions. When users plan on a public version in a story, SAC automatically creates an implicit private version behind the scenes. This version isn’t visible to the user but introduces system overhead, especially in models with large datasets or when multiple users are editing simultaneously. To mitigate this, it’s crucial to explicitly define the planning area in the model settings and enable it within the story. Doing so significantly reduces resource consumption during public version edits. Key recommendations include:
  • Configure a Targeted Planning Area: Set a focused scope based on business needs, using data access control, data locking, or both to restrict editable data.
  • Avoid Full Dataset Scope: Limiting the planning area prevents unnecessary data loading and improves performance.
  • Use Data Access Control(DAC): Define which users can write to specific dimensions—such as company codes or profit centers—to ensure secure and relevant access.
  • Apply Data Locking: Protect actuals from being overwritten by locking them from edits.
  • Enable Dynamic Planning Area: Set “Auto-generate based on table context” as the default. This allows the planning area to adjust automatically based on filters, story context, or table layout—ensuring users only load what they need.

SAC Planning Best Practices

  • Use Unbooked Data selectively: Enable unbooked data only when necessary—typically for planning use cases. Since it triggers resource-intensive backend queries, it's best disabled for reporting scenarios to preserve performance.
  • Implement DAC: Always activate DAC on relevant dimensions to enforce row-level security. This ensures users only see and interact with data within their authorized scope, reducing system load during public version edits. DAC should be configured during the model design phase. DAC can be turned ON in the Model Dimension through the Read/Write Property or the Data Access Filter in Role by turning the Model Data Privacy ON so DAC can be combined with role-based restrictions. Use DAC primarily on planning-relevant dimensions (E.g. Cost Center, Profit Center, Region), not on all dimensions.
  • Complement with Data Locks :  While DAC governs who can read/write data, Data Locks control when data can be modified (e.g., freezing approved budgets). This combination enhances performance, especially in multi-user environments. Minimize driving dimensions when using data locking to reduce overhead.
  • Define Validation Rules: Ensure users can only edit valid combinations of dimension members. This is particularly important for models with large dimension tables and helps maintain data integrity while improving performance.
  • Limit Private versions: Excessive private versions—especially when multiple users are editing simultaneously—can strain system resources. Regularly clean up unused private versions to maintain system efficiency.
  • Manage Date Granularity: For models with day-level granularity, consider isolating them into separate models. Use cross-model copy data actions to transfer aggregated data, reducing complexity and improving performance.
  • Use Modeler option ‘Optimize Story Building Performance’ : This prevents the automatic refresh of data during story design. When importing or writing back datasets, use filters or pre-aggregation to reduce data volume

Calculations/Data Actions

  • Prioritize Model-Level Formulas: Define calculations within the modeler rather than at the story level to reduce query load and improve responsiveness.
  • Offload Complex: Logic to Data Actions Use data actions for advanced formulas and heavy computations instead of embedding them directly in stories.
  • Restrict Execution Scope: Use the MEMBERSET statement to narrow the scope of data actions. A tightly defined scope minimizes processing time and resource usage.
  • Limit Iteration Range: Keep calculation loops (IF, FOREACH) as focused as possible. Broad iteration across dimensions can degrade performance.
  • Aggregate at the Highest Logical Level: Design calculations to occur at the most aggregated node feasible to reduce data volume and complexity.
  • Avoid Copying Calculated Accounts: Copying calculated accounts or non-standard aggregations is resource intensive. Prefer copying raw fact data when possible.
  • Configure Advanced Formulas Thoughtfully: All steps in advanced formulas execute sequentially and materialize in the model. Use variable members to streamline logic and avoid unnecessary commits.
  • Minimize Query Calls: Reduce the number of DATA() and RESULTLOOKUP() statements—each call triggers a backend query.
  • Restricted Measures Over Exception Aggregations: Exception aggregations (e.g., MIN, MAX, AVERAGE across hierarchies) are computationally expensive. Use restricted measures and advanced formulas when possible.
  • Simplify Formula Structures: Avoid breaking formulas into too many sub-steps, which increases processing overhead.
  • Recompile After Model Changes:  If performance drops after model updates, re-save the advanced formula or data action to trigger recompilation and optimization.
  • Centralize Execution for Large Volumes:  Run data actions centrally via an admin user when handling large datasets. For decentralized execution, ensure scope is tightly defined.
  • Trigger Actions Judiciously:  Avoid frequent or unnecessary data action runs. Execute only when required to conserve resources.
  • Monitor Execution Time:  Use the Data Action Monitor to track duration and identify slow-running actions.
  • Use Job Monitor for Diagnostics: Regularly review run history and step-level details to pinpoint bottlenecks and optimize performance.
  • Simplify IF Statements: Reduce reliance on IF statements by using logical operators like AND or applying filters. Each IF creates a subquery, so use sparingly.
  • Leverage Predictive Planning: Use predictive features to generate accurate forecasts based on historical data, accelerating planning cycles and improving decision-making.

Backend HANA/BW considerations

HANA modelling

  • Optimize HANA Views by following guidelines for modelling and performance tuning.
  • Perform Calculations Post-Aggregation: Whenever possible, structure views to calculate after aggregation to reduce data volume and improve speed.
  • Join on Indexed Columns: Use keys or indexed columns for joins instead of calculated fields to enhance query performance.
  • Push Logic to HANA: Keep calculations and logic within HANA to leverage pushdown capabilities and minimize SAC-side processing.
  • Blend in HANA, Not SAC: Perform data linking and blending operations in HANA to reduce complexity and improve responsiveness.
  • Apply Filters Early: Early filtering reduces data load and improves query execution time.
  • Hide Unused Dimensions in SAC: Remove unnecessary metadata from SAC models to streamline performance and reduce clutter.

BW modelling

  • Design Efficient Queries: Limit the number of dimensions and hide unnecessary key figures to reduce query payload and improve responsiveness.
  • Use BW Variables Over SAC Filters: BW variables are processed server-side and offer better performance than applying filters within SAC stories.
  • Define Restricted Key Figures: in BW Avoid creating restricted key figures in SAC remote models. Instead, configure them directly in BW for optimized execution.
  • Minimize Cascading Page Filters: Page-level filters that trigger cascading effects across widgets can slow down performance. Use them sparingly and strategically.
  • Enable Query Merge: Activate query merge to consolidate backend calls, reducing latency and improving load times.
  • Enable HTTP/2 Protocol: Improves data transfer efficiency between SAC and BW, especially for large datasets.
  • Increase Parallel Sessions: Configure BW data sources to support more parallel sessions, enhancing concurrency and user experience.
  • Apply BI Authorizations for Data Security: Use BW’s built-in data-level security to control access and ensure users only retrieve data relevant to their roles.

Story Building Recommendations

Story Structure & Layout

  • Use Optimized or Unified Story Experience: Adopt the latest story building interface for enhanced performance, flexibility, and design capabilities.
  • Leverage Composites as Reusable Widgets: Composites are stored as SAC artifacts and can be reused across stories. They support both canvas and responsive layouts and allow story-level features like filters and bookmarks to apply seamlessly. Benefits include faster story creation, reduced maintenance, standardized design, and support for parallel development.
  • Use Responsive Layouts: Responsive pages automatically adjust to screen size and load faster. Unified stories offer advanced responsive rule configurations for precise control.

Content Design & Performance Optimization

  • Request Only What’s Needed: Break down information into manageable layers. Use summary or landing pages with hyperlinks to detailed views.
  • Minimize Page Count and Widget Load: Reduce the number of pages and limit data-heavy widgets per page to improve load times and user experience.
  • Optimize Charts and Tables:
    • Avoid charts with more than 500 data points.
    • Limit the number of charts per page to reduce backend requests.
    • Split large tables into smaller ones with fewer KPIs or measures.
    • Limit the number of cells and descriptive columns for readability.
    • Avoid excessive formatting rules and in-cell charts/calculations.
  • Use Lightweight Visuals:  Replace large image files with lightweight SVGs to reduce rendering time.

Filtering & Data Handling:

  • Implement Filters Strategically: Apply filters at the document level rather than creating generic views. Use page filters instead of individual chart filters. Avoid loading all data and filtering afterward.
  • Limit Hierarchy Depth: in Filters Deep hierarchies can slow down performance—use only necessary levels.
  • Minimize Data Blending: Sources Keep the number of blended data sources low to reduce complexity and improve responsiveness.
  • Pause Data Refresh During Design: Use the “Pause Data Refresh” option to optimize story loading while building.

Security & Access Control

  • Test With User Roles: Validate story performance using roles with end user authorizations—not just the admin role—to simulate real-world usage.
  • Apply Data Access Control (DAC): Ensure users only see data relevant to their role. For example, use filters for company code and profit center rather than displaying all dimensions.

Planning-Specific Tips

  • Use Fluid Data Entry Mode: This default mode offers better performance and interactivity. Avoid Single Data Entry mode, which is slower.
  • Enable Planning Only Where Needed: Activate planning features on tables only when required. Disable planning in the builder panel if not used.

Latest Performance Improvements

  • New Table Build Experience:  Optimized Stories – Edit Mode Enhancements.
    • Blended Tables: Initial page loading is faster.
    • Calculations: Automatically retained when tables are copied.
    • Improved Filtering & Sorting: More efficient workflows and reduced query errors.
    • Ghost Table: Instant layout preview before data loads
  • Story Design Optimization:
    • Performance recommendations in Edit Mode available for story designers in the optimized story experience.
    • Available for widget, page, and stories levels.
  • Preload pages
    • It can be enabled in edit mode under Data Refresh->Loading Optimization Settings-> Preload Pages.
    • Preloading will initialize parts of the next and previous page, so switching to these pages will now be faster.

If performance issues persist despite optimization efforts, SAC offers a suite of diagnostic tools to help pinpoint the root cause. These tools provide visibility into query execution, data action performance, and story load behavior. For detailed guidance on using these diagnostics, refer to the official SAP Help documentation or reach out to SAP Support for expert help.

entry.title: Archive SAC Change Docs into Datasphere
entry.content:
Using SAC data change documents, you can track (audit) the data changes made to any planning model. SAP Analytics Cloud logs all changes to the transaction data of that model when users publish data from private versions to public versions.

Note that a data change log has up to 2^31 (i.e., 2,147,384,648, or ~2 billion) records. When the data change log reaches its size limit, publishing data will fail, and you will see the following message:

Publish cannot be performed because the data audit table has reached the maximum number of rows.

To avoid this issue, consider periodically downloading log entries as a backup before deleting them.

This document shows a design to back up SAC audit logs into Datasphere. Using Datasphere dataflow to back up change documents from the SAC Data Export Service via a Cloud Data Integration adapter-based connection, it can back up and preserve the SAC audit log history, which is necessary for regular housekeeping in SAC due to storage capacity limits.

 

DES: data export service

CDI: cloud data integration

 

Note: In SAC seamless planning or in BDC, the SAC model definition and calculation logic remain within SAC, while the persistence for planning data and change documents are stored in SAP Datasphere, so that both systems are closely linked - without the effort of manual data transfers. Therefore, the solution might not be necessary if the SAC change documents are already stored in Datasphere.

 

The following steps outline the implementation of the solution.

In SAC, System – Administration – App Integration, create an OAuth client with Access to the Data Export Service.

 

 

In SAC, keep the OAuth Client URLs for later configuration of the connection in Datasphere.

 

 

In SAC, copy the OAuth Client ID and Client Secret for later configuration of the connection in Datasphere.

 

In Datasphere, in a space, create a Cloud Data Integration connection pointing to the SAC Data Export Service. The URL is in the format of

https://<your domain>/api/v1/dataexport/administration

 

In the connections management screen, validate the connection, and make sure the Data Flows feature is now enabled. It shall give the following message after validation on the connection.

Connection “SAC DES Change Docs” is valid. – Data flows are enabled. – Replication flows are not supported. – Remote tables are enabled.

 

In SAC, open the model with the Audit Data flag switched on, and note down the model ID in the rear part of the URL. For instance:

https://<your domain name>/sap/fpa/ui/app.html?sap-ui-theme=sap_belize#/modeler&/m/model/C4003n1icbi0loo9lvgv7t4pu41

 

In Datasphere, Data Builder- Create a Data Flow to load SAC audit logs into a target table.

  1. Use the model id to find the SAC source in the connection for the source node in the data flow.
  2. To make the daily backup more efficient, an exemplary expression implemented in the projection node can be: "Audit_Time" >= ADD_DAYS(NOW(), -1).
  3. To preserve the audit logs history that might be regularly cleaned in SAC, use Append mode on the target table for UPSERT.

 

 

 

In Datasphere, execute the data flow to load SAC audit logs and verify that the data is now present in Datasphere. Then, delete the audit logs in SAC, execute the data flow again to check that the audit logs history has been preserved after cleansing audit logs in SAC.

 

Last but not least, you may also develop an analytic model on top of the audit logs history table in Datasphere for analytics and build a report or visualization in SAC.

Note:

CDI connection type also supports the remote table as well as the data flow feature.

Remote table can use the following replication types, but none of those replications can well preserve the change document history.

  • Replication (snapshot)
  • Replication (real-time)

entry.title: Choosing the Right SAP Analytics Tool: Features, Benefits, and Strategy
entry.content:
Introduction : 

Within an organization's data and analytics strategy, SAP provides a portfolio of analytics solutions, including SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics, SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), and SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), each with a specific function. To assist clients in selecting the best option for their requirements, a comparative analysis of their salient characteristics and advantages is provided below.

SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics

Summary: This solution, which is directly integrated into the SAP S/4HANA ERP system, offers real-time analytics on operational data without requiring data replication.

Key Benefits :

  • Operational Reporting in Real Time: Get the most recent information straight from the ERP system.
  • Views of Core Data Services (CDS): For customizable reporting, use virtual data models.
  • Predefined KPIs and Dashboards: Use unconventional content to gain rapid insights.
  • Fiori-Based User Interface: Enhanced user experience through intuitive design.

Benefits:

  • Immediate Decision-Making: Facilitates quick actions based on current data.
  • Simplified Infrastructure: Eliminates the need for separate data warehousing solutions.
  • Seamless Integration: Embedded within the core ERP system, ensuring consistency.

 

SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

Summary: A cloud-based platform combining business intelligence, planning, and predictive analytics, SAC connects to various data sources, including SAP and non-SAP systems.

Key Features:

  • Advanced Analytics: Utilize AI-driven insights and predictive modelling.
  • Planning Capabilities: Integrate financial planning and budgeting processes.
  • Collaboration Tools: Facilitate real-time discussions and decision-making.
  • Mobile Accessibility: Access analytics on-the-go through optimized dashboards.

Benefits:

  • Comprehensive Insights: Consolidates data from multiple sources for holistic analysis.
  • Enhanced Forecasting: Improves accuracy in planning and budgeting.
  • Scalability: Cloud infrastructure supports growth and flexibility.
