SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC)

 Overview: A fully managed SaaS solution that unifies and governs SAP and third-party data, enabling advanced analytics and AI-driven insights across the organization.

Key Features:

  • Data Integration: Connects disparate data sources into a unified platform.
  • AI and ML Capabilities: Leverages machine learning for predictive analytics.
  • Prebuilt Applications: Offers industry-specific solutions and dashboards.
  • Data Governance: Ensures data quality and compliance across the organization.

Benefits:

  • Accelerated Decision-Making: Provides timely insights for informed decisions.
  • Reduced Complexity: Simplifies data management and analytics processes.
  • Enhanced Collaboration: Fosters cross-departmental data sharing and insights.

 

Comparative Study

Recommendation:

  • Choose SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics if your primary need is real-time, operational reporting directly within your ERP system, with minimal infrastructure overhead.

  • Opt for SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) when you require advanced analytics, predictive modeling, and planning capabilities across various data sources, with a focus on scalability and collaboration.

  • Consider SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) if your organization seeks a unified platform for data integration, governance, and AI-driven insights, encompassing both SAP and third-party data sources.

Thank you for your time.  Stay connected for further updates on Analytics !

-With Warm Regards :  GIRI

entry.title: Use BTP destination service to call SAC multi-actions API
entry.content:
Based on the standard product document, this blog shows practical implementation steps to call SAC multi actions API from a BTP destination service that can be used in BTP CAPM service.

https://help.sap.com/docs/connectivity/sap-btp-connectivity-cf/user-propagation-via-saml-2-0-bearer-assertion-flow

 


1. In SAC System/Administration/App Integration, create an oAuth client with API Access and SAML2.0 Grant. Note down the Client ID and Secret. Some blogs say using Interactive Usage for the purpose, but the testing shows no return of SAC auth token.

 

 

2.  Note down oAuth2SAML Token URLs

 

3. Note down your SAC multi-action URL

 

4. In BTP Cockpit, create a BTP destination service that has a destination pointing to SAC oAuth Client and create a service key with a pair of client id and client credential. The service key is only used for Postman testing, but it’s unnecessary for the bound BTP app.

 

 

5. Download BTP signing certificate and IDP metadata from BTP destinations at sub account level. Kindly note that a destination service is created in dev space and bound with an BTP application.

 

 

6. In SAC, create a trusted identify provider maintained accordingly. The provider name should come from Entity ID of the downloaded IDP metadata and the signing certificate should come the downloaded trust from BTP destinations.

 

 

 

7. Add the userIdSource property to the BTP destination to allow passing the BTP access token attribute to SAC auth token.

 

 

 

8. Get a BTP access token using password credentials grant type.

 

 

 

9. Verify the BTP access token if it contains the email attribute.

 

 

 

 

10. Use the BTP access token to call BTP destination service to get a SAC auth token.

 

 

 

11. Use the SAC auth token to get a SAC CSRF token.

 

12. Use both the SAC auth token and SAC CSRF token to execute SAC multi-action.

13. Use the SAC auth token to get SAC multi-action execution status and verify it was successful.

14. How to allow BTP CAPM to use the destination service to call the SAC multi-action.

a. Update the package.json to have a reference to the BTP destination in the destination service that has been bound with the BTP app.

 

  "cds": {

    "requires": {

      "uaa": {

        "kind": "xsuaa"

      },

      "db": {

        "kind": "hana"

      },

      "CapExDestinationForUI": {

        "kind": "rest",

        "credentials": {

          "destination": "sac-multi-actions-dest_CLONING"

        },

        "csrf": {

          "method": "get",

 

 

          "url": "https://ps-trial.us10.hcs.cloud.sap/api/v1/csrf"

        }

      }

    }

  }

 

b. In a CAPM service event, connect to the destination and use POST method to call the multi action URL. It by default uses different Content-Type that might cause 415 Error, so pass application/json to overwrite the default to make sure it’s successful.

 

      let service = await cds.connect.to('CapExDestinationForUI');

      let projects = await service.tx(req).send("POST", "/multiActions/t.16:9C88BE058AA23F014E86756BBDB404D3/executions", req.data, { "Content-Type": "application/json" });

entry.title: Full-Page Fit vs. Scrollable Dashboards in SAC which one is better?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I'd like to discuss a common dilemma developers face when it comes to designing a dashboard in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC).
Should I design the dashboard such that it fits entirely within the browser window (Full-Page Fit)? or should I design the dashboard such that it has a scroll? Would the customer be okay with having to scroll up and down to see the contents of the dashboard? 🙄

So, the design process begins even before we decide to click Create Story.
To Tackle this problem, I will be elaborating both the scenarios for you to make an informed decision while designing your next dashboard.

Difference between both the Dashboard Fit:

Assuming we are seeing the dashboard in a normal sized laptop screen [1366 x 768px] not a 1080p HD one. A Full-Page Fit Dashboard ensures all content is visible without scrolling, while a Scrollable Dashboard allows content to extend vertically or horizontally beyond the initial view, requiring user interaction to access additional information.

This choice significantly impacts user experience and performance. Both has its own advantages and disadvantages. Let's dive deep to understand the pros and cons of each type. 

Full-Page Fit Dashboard: (Everything visible in a single glance)

 Here in the above screenshot, see how all the KPIs presented within a single screen and there is no scroll to the right and bottom of the dashboards. This means that it is well within the boundaries of our 1366 x 768 px canvas.

Advantages

  • All KPIs are visible at a single glance, enabling quick decision-making.
  • No need to scroll, which is ideal for users who prefer a single-screen overview.

Disadvantages

  • Each KPI has less room, potentially less real estate and more congestion.
  • All widgets are triggered simultaneously, sending backend requests that can strain system resources.
  • Heavy widgets like tables may take longer to load, making the dashboard appear sluggish.

Performance Statistics

All the KPIs visible in viewport have triggered a backend request and rendered.

It's like going to a restaurant and saying bring me everything you have, even when you know you won't be able to eat everything they bring. Wasteful.👎

Total render time ~9.5s 

All the visible KPIs have triggered a backend request and are rendered at Frontend.

Dashboard with Scroll (You gotta scroll to see what you want)

 Scroll Section 1Scroll Section 2

Here in the above screenshot, see how we have a scroll to the right of the dashboard. This means that the KPIs are spaced out more and exceeds the page's default height of 768px, therefore the user would get a scroll when accessing the dashboard.

Advantages

  • More space per KPI allows for better viewability and detailed insights.
  • SAC’s viewport loading ensures only visible widgets are triggered, reducing initial load time and backend traffic.
  • Less frequently used or heavier components can be placed lower on the page.

Disadvantages

  • Users may miss the overall picture and need to scroll to compare KPIs.
  • Scrolling back and forth can hinder quick analysis and decision-making.

Performance Statistics

All the KPIs that has been viewed initially have triggered a backend request and rendered. The Un scrolled portion doesn't trigger any backend request neither doesn't render until we preview it.

This is like going to the restaurant and placing an order and post eating the main course you get to decide if you want to take on dessert. Only what is required is being consumed here. Resourceful 👍

Total render time ~8s

 Only KPIs visible during initial preview has been rendered

Finding the Middle Ground: Tab Strips

To balance usability and performance, developers can use Tab Strip.

These are container widgets used within a SAC story to organize content into separate, switchable tabs. They allow users to view different components, such as charts or tables, within a single application by providing a navigation area to select and display the content of each tab.

Tab strip - summary sectionTab strip - Table section

Here in the above screenshot, see how the dashboard is still fitted within the canvas and also having the benefits of loading what is required.

As we have also bifurcated the components into summary and table section. The heavier/Less frequently viewed KPIs are places in the subsequent tab strips, therefore reducing the initial load.

Benefits of Tab Strips

  • Essential KPIs are displayed upfront, while heavier or less frequently accessed components (e.g., raw data tables) are placed in separate tabs.
  • SAC’s default viewport loading ensures only visible components are triggered, reducing backend load and improving responsiveness.
  • Tabs offer a cleaner and better UI/UX.

Performance Statistics

Only the Default tab strip KPIs have triggered a backend request and has been rendered. The heavier KPIs which hasn't been previewed is still untriggered and unrendered.
Total render time ~7.5s

Only the Default tab strip KPIs have triggered a backend request and has been rendered

Key Principle: "What You See Is What Loads"

SAC's viewport optimization means that only the visible components are loaded initially. This explains why Full-Page Fit dashboards can be performance intensive as everything is triggered at once. In contrast, scrollable dashboards and tab-based layouts defer loading of non-visible components, enhancing performance.

However, it’s important to note that once a user navigates to hidden sections or tabs, those components will be triggered, potentially causing a brief delay.

Final Take away

The choice between a Full-Page Fit and a Scrollable Dashboard should be guided by user requirements and usage patterns. Developers must engage with users' early phases in the design process to understand:

  • Which KPIs are most frequently accessed?
  • Is a single-screen overview preferred?
  • Are users comfortable with scrolling or tab navigation?

I hope this article was helpful. Which one do you prefer? Let me know your doubts and opinions in the comments below!

References:

Using the Loading Optimization Setting on a Story Level

entry.title: SAP Data and Analytics Forum 18.-19.11.2025
entry.content:
We look forward to welcoming  you on the 18th to 19th. November at this year’s German speaking SAP Data and Analytics Forum. An exciting program with inspiring lectures awaits you.  

There are two ways to participate in the event:  

Option 1: You only visit the first day, in virtual format  

 The first day is free and virtual. Current trends and developments in Data and Analytics are discussed here. From best practices to new technologies and applications such as SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere, you will be able to gain valuable insights and expand your knowledge.  Key sessions will cover the strategic direction and roadmap of the SAP Business Data Cloud, highlight the latest innovations and feature enhancements, and explore advanced planning capabilities enabled by seamless planning.

Sign up here for the first free and virtual day.

 Option 2: Join Both Days in Walldorf or Virtually

 The second day will be delivered in a hybrid format, enabling participation either on site at the SAP Training Center in Walldorf or virtually. Building on the strategic and technological perspectives from day one, you will dive deeper into SAP’s data and analytics portfolio. Through expert-led sessions and live demonstrations, you will explore the SAP Business Data Cloud in detail – from its architecture and native data warehousing capabilities with SAP Datasphere to its integration with SAP Enterprise Architecture Designer, SAP Data Hub, SAP Embedded Analytics, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Intelligent Applications.

Between sessions, “Meet the Expert” formats give you the opportunity to address your specific technical and business questions directly with SAP specialists.

You will also have the chance to join a guided tour of the SAP Experience Center, illustrating sustainable value creation across an end-to-end solution landscape, and discover the SAP S.Mart Store as a real-world example of applied retail innovation.

The day will close with an evening networking event – the perfect opportunity to exchange ideas, share experiences, and build valuable connections in a relaxed setting.

entry.title: What's New in SAP Analytics Cloud Modeling Extensions & Integration QRC4 2025 Release
entry.content:
Purpose

Hello SAP Community Colleagues,

I am delighted to share some fantastic new Data Integration & Conversion features made available inside the modeling area of SAP Analytics Cloud, within Business Data Cloud!

Overview

Here is a short overview of each feature:

1. Data Export API – Master Data Hierarchies

The Data Export API has been extended to support the export of master data parent-child and level-based hierarchies. 

2. Data Export API – Seamless Planning Support for Public Dimensions

The Data Export API has been extended to support the export of master data from public dimensions that reside in a Datasphere workspace.

3. Data Export API – Seamless Planning Support for Fact Data Delta

The Data Export API has been extended to support the export of fact data delta changes from a SAP Analytics Cloud standard model that resides in a Datasphere space.

4. Dimension Unit Property Enhancement

In Unit Conversion, a dimension containing a unit property now displays a member selector dialog consisting of a list of Unit Symbols & Unit Descriptions that are contained in the Standard Unit & Unit Description tables.

5. New Member Selector dialog in Modeling

A new member selector dialog has been introduced into the Modeling area of SAC, replacing the previous member selection dialog.

 

Let’s now investigate each topic in further detail:

1. Data Export API – Master Data Hierarchies

The Data Export API has been extended to support the export of Master Data Level-Based & Parent-Child Hierarchies that are part of a standard model residing in SAP Analytics Cloud.  This includes master data stored in public or private dimensions.

The export of Master Data Hierarchies is also supported for standard models that are saved on a Datasphere space.

Level-Based Hierarchies

To allow the export of Level-Based hierarchies, a new endpoint has been created called

{BaseURL}/providers/{namespaceID}/{providerID}/{DimensionName}Master 

Note: Make sure to replace {namespaceID} and {providerID} with the correct IDs and to replace {DimensionName} with the name of your dimension.

Parent-Child Hierarchies

To allow the export of Parent-Child hierarchies, a new endpoint has been created called

{BaseURL}/providers/{namespaceID}/{providerID}/{DimensionName}MasterWithHierarchy

Note: Make sure to replace {namespaceID} and {providerID} with the correct IDs and to replace {DimensionName} with the name of your dimension.

For each Parent-Child hierarchy of the dimension, each row will have 3 additional columns compared to when using the {DimensionName}Master endpoint.

These 3 columns are: 

  • {HierarchyName}_PARENTID - the id of the parent node in the hierarchy. 
  • {HierarchyName}_PREVID - the previous node which shares the same parent as this one in the hierarchy. 
  • {HierarchyName}_ORDERID - the index of this node in the list of nodes that share the parent node. 

Master Data Hierarchy export jobs can be executed using 2-legged (machine to machine) or 3-legged (Authorized User) access.  

2. Data Export API – Seamless Planning Support for Public Dimensions

The Data Export API has been extended to support the export of Master Data from Public Dimensions that reside in a Datasphere workspace using the existing PublicDimensionData endpoint.

{BaseURL}/providers/{namespaceID}/{providerID}/PublicDimensionData

Note: Make sure to replace {namespaceID} and {providerID} with the correct IDs. 

Figure 1: Sample export of Public Dimension Data on a Datasphere space using the PublicDimensionData Endpoint

Public Dimension export jobs can be executed using 2-legged (machine to machine) or 3-legged (Authorized User) access. 

Authentication checks are in place, for 3-legged accounts, to ensure that access to the Datasphere space is permitted.

Figure 2: Authorization Check Prevents Export from a Datasphere Space.

This brings feature parity between the export of SAC public dimensions and those saved on a Datasphere space.

3. Data Export API – Seamless Planning Support for Fact Data Delta

The Data Export API has been extended to support the export of Fact Data Delta changes from a SAP Analytics Cloud standard model that resides in a Datasphere space.  This includes support for Delta Difference & Delta Aggregation.

The API Subscriptions tab in the modeler has been enabled to allow for the delta extraction of models residing in a Datasphere space.

Figure 3: API Subscriptions Dialog Visible for SAC Models residing in a Datasphere Space

The existing Fact Data API endpoint names will also now work within this landscape using 2-legged and 3-legged authentications.

/providers/{NamespaceID}/{ProviderID}/FactData

/providers/{NamespaceID}/{ProviderID}/FactDataAggregation

This brings feature parity between the delta extraction on SAC models and models saved on a Datasphere space.

See my previous blogs covering Fact Data Difference & Fact Data Aggregation.

What’s New in SAP Analytics Cloud Modeling Extensions & Integration QRC3 2024 Release

What's New in SAP Analytics Cloud Modeling Extensions & Integration QRC3 2025 Release

4. Dimension Unit Property Enhancement

In Unit Conversion, a dimension containing a unit property now displays a member selector dialog consisting of a list of Unit Symbols & Unit Descriptions that are contained in the Standard Unit & Unit Description tables.

Previously, modelers had to navigate to the Standard Unit table, to locate the correct Unit ID and Unit Symbol and then switch to a dimension to enter the correct unit.  The member selector dialog  on unit properties of a dimension, in the grid view, reduces the risk of data-entry errors.

Figure 4: Value Help on Dimension Unit Property

5. New Member Selector dialog in Modeling

A new member selector dialog has been introduced into the Modeling area of SAC, replacing the previous member selection dialog. 

This improved flexible dialog provides an item ID and item description in the display.

Figure 5: New Member Selector in Modeling

The new dialog can be found in the following areas:

  • Generic dimensions > Data Access Control, Hierarchies, Unit Property
  • Account dimensions > Data Locking Ownership, Responsible column
  • Data Management > API Subscription filters
  • Calculation Workspace > Grid view – Exception aggregation / Required dimensions, preview panel filters
  • Formula Editor > Dynamic time dimension
  • Model Structure > delete facts
  • Variables

6. More new Modeling Features...

Some additional new and exciting features in the Modeling area of SAP Analytics Cloud coming in QRC4 2025 include:

  • Consuming a Datasphere view as an external version into an SAC Planning Model.
  • Consuming Google Big Query as an external version into an SAC Planning Model.
  • Introduction of Clean and Replace Subset of Data option into the Data Upload Starter.

Conclusion

In summary, the following new features and updates have been introduced to the Modeling Extensions and Integration areas of SAP Analytics Cloud, within Business Data Cloud, as part of QRC4 2025 release.

1. The Data Export API has been extended to support the export of master data parent-child and level-based hierarchies. 

2. The Data Export API has been extended to support the export of master data from public dimensions that reside in a Datasphere space.

3. The Data Export API has been extended to support the export of fact data delta changes from an SAP Analytics Cloud standard model that resides in a Datasphere space.

4. Dimension properties of type Unit now offer a member selector dialog containing a list of Unit Symbols and Unit Descriptions obtained from the Standard Unit & Unit Description tables.

 5. A new member selector dialog has been introduced into the Modeling area of SAC

 

A comprehensive list of SAC features for each QRC release can be found in our What's New - 2025 Releases Guide.

If you have any questions, feel free to comment below or post a question to our SAP Analytics Cloud Questions & Answers forum.

See this SAP Knowledge Base Article if you’d like to learn more about FastTrack and Quarterly Release Cycle releases.

For further information, visit our SAP Analytics Cloud Community pages to find more product information, best practices, and more. 

To find out more about QRC release dates, see SAP Analytics Cloud tenants on Quarterly Release Cycle (QRC) updates in 2025.

Check out our SAP Road Map Explorer to see more upcoming features of SAP Analytics Cloud.

Thanks for reading!

entry.title: Product Direction and Evolution of the New Table Build Experience
entry.content:
Introduction

This document reflects the status of the Table Build Experience in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) as of Q3 2025.

It aims to guide story designers and stakeholders during the transition to the new experience and to provide visibility into its planned evolution.

Please note that some features and restrictions are temporary and subject to change as SAP continues to enhance SAC in upcoming releases.

 

The New Table Build Experience

With the Q3 2025 release, SAP Analytics Cloud introduces the new Table Build Experience for the Optimized Design Mode.

This redesign marks a major step forward in how tables are created, configured, and consumed in SAC.

The new experience offers a more intuitive workflow for story designers, aligning closely with the Chart Builder, while also laying the foundation for future innovations.

All new capabilities and innovations introduced with this experience are detailed in the following SAP Community article:

🔗The New Table Building Experience in SAP Analytics Cloud

In short, the new Table Build Experience is not just a cosmetic update. It represents a strategic foundation for SAC.

 

Existing Unsupported Features and Restrictions

As with any major redesign, the initial release does not yet offer full feature parity with the legacy table, which is why the new Table Build Experience is currently available through an Opt-In option.

While the core capabilities are already in place, some features are still under development.

The complete and up-to-date list of unsupported features and restrictions (as of QRC3 2025) is available in the official documentation:

🔗Unsupported Features and Restrictions: New Table Build Experience

These limitations are important to keep in mind, especially when switching to the New Table Build Experience.

However, they should be viewed in context: these limitations are temporary by nature and will progressively be removed.

 

Product Direction for the New Table Build Experience

Many of the current gaps are expected to be closed in the near future, with several already addressed as SAC continues to harmonize and extend its table capabilities.

The following roadmap illustrates what and when SAP plans to lift the current restrictions and achieve full feature parity.

 

Share Your Feedback

We want this transition to the New Table Build Experience to be as smooth and valuable as possible.

Your feedback directly helps us improve both the product and its documentation.

Please let us know your thoughts, your input is highly appreciated and will actively influence future enhancements to SAP Analytics Cloud.

entry.title: Extend existing planning scenarios of SAP BPC/ BW-IP in SAP BDC
entry.content:
This blog post is a joint work of @IsabelWichmann and @irinasheftelevich 

Financial Planner´s Overview page in SAP Analytics Cloud

MOTIVATION

In today's fast-paced business world, the ability to effectively steer and lead an organisation is fundamental for achieving strategic goals and maintaining a competitive edge. A key success criterion is the capacity to fully harness and derive value from organisational data. Many companies struggle with data problems, such as fragmented information, outdated systems, and the super important task of preparing data for emerging technologies like AI. Recognising these challenges, we are excited to introduce a blog series dedicated to showcasing the substantial business value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in the context of planning and analytics.

The motivation behind this initiative is to provide a comprehensive exploration of how SAP BDC capabilities as essential instruments, facilitating robust strategic alignment and guiding effective decision-making processes across diverse organisational requirements. We aim to illustrate how SAP BDC, equipped with powerful data management, planning, analytics and innovative AI capabilities, empowers organisations with enhanced business steering agility by providing real-time insights, streamlined data management, and automated decision support – going from insights to action, helps mainly leaders guide their businesses with precision.

Our blog series will provide valuable insights for decision-makers seeking to harness SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to enhance operational efficiency, optimise resource allocation, and achieve long-term objectives. By featuring detailed planning & analytics topics, the series will illustrate the transformative impact of SAP BDC in addressing the operational complexities of today’s business environment. This first introductory blog post will spotlight the strategic advantages of SAP BDC, particularly in the context of Business Steering, setting the stage for a deeper exploration of its benefits throughout the blog series.

There are several blog posts in the series that will cover advantages of SAP BDC in the context of business steering, so please stay tuned for the upcoming blogs:

  1. The Value of SAP BDC in the context of business steering 
  2.  Planning & Analytics is an essential part of SAP BDC  
  3. Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC
  4. Is AI going to “retire” a dashboard?
  5. Simulations, a game changer in today’s volatile world
  6. Extend existing planning scenarios of SAP BPC/BW-IP in SAP BDC (THIS BLOG POST)
  7. Real-time steering with LIVE planning
  8. PaPM - The role of business calculation engine in business steering
  9. Self – service analytics and real time business steering
  10. Business steering powered by AI agents
  11. Leverage data products in the context of planning & forecasting
  12. Introducing AI/ML capabilities by SAP Databricks

INTRODUCTION

SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC) is a fully managed SaaS solution that unifies and governs all SAP data and seamlessly connects with third-party data, giving line-of-business leaders context to make even more impactful decisions. As an evolution of our industry-leading data, planning, and analytics solutions, SAP Business Data Cloud brings together SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Business Warehouse with a unified experience that delivers transformational insights across all lines of business. 

To fully leverage benefits of SAP BDC in the Planning and Analytics area, it is worth to consider modernizing the Planning engine.  SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) is the component that delivers cutting-edge analytics and planning capabilities while providing real-time insights powered by AI and machine learning. It integrates seamlessly with SAP Datasphere to offer a unified data analysis experience (The Value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in The ... - SAP Community).

But how to get there? For those customers who are searching for a new planning engine the situation is clear. SAC is the clear strategic direction for the planning processes and xP&A. For those customers who are now using an SAP BW based planning engine like SAP BPC or BW-IP the path can be not as straightforward, so we are recommending evaluating the possible ways to start with SAP BDC as the future-state landscape.

SAP BPC PLANNING SCENARIOS WITHIN SAP BDC

There are three scenarios how you can go forward with SAP Business Planning and Consolidation (SAP BPC) as part of SAP BDC.

Based on insights from the original SAP blog on moving from SAP BPC to SAC, we would like to refresh and update scenarios of moving from SAP BPC —into the world of SAP BDC and SAC.

SCENARIO 1: MOVE

Picture 1: Moving to SAC planning at your own pace

Target Landscape: SAC Planning + BDC as the data foundation

This is the option where planning use cases would be completely moved from SAP BPC into SAC. In this case we talk about re-implementation, but you can still reuse some of the things that you have created. For example, you could build a SAC planning model based on the query that is coming from your SAP BPC (embedded model, running on the SAP BW system). That way all relevant dimensions (including its members and hierarchies) could be recreated quite easily. 

What´s new with SAP BDC?

  1. Seamless planning, links SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) with SAP Datasphere so that SAC model data (facts & master data) can be stored directly in Datasphere. This reduces data duplication, ensures real-time availability, and allows further processing and extension via Datasphere’s capabilities. ( Seamless planning between SAP Analytics Cloud and ... - SAP Community )
  2. Part of BW modernisation process. SAP Analytics cloud can replace SAP BPC and BW-IP, become the new modern planning engine and reduce dependency on SAP BW. It can help to shrink BW and together with SAP Profitability and Performance management solution and Datasphere can provide a foundation for an End-to-End enterprise performance management process.

SCENARIO 2: COMPLEMENT (=LIVE Planning)

Picture 2: Live Planning

 

In this scenario we are using SAC as a planning/forecasting data entry UX and as well for data analysis (variance analysis in reports and dashboards for example). In other words, users enter data via the SAC data entry form, and the data is being persisted directly in the SAP BPC embedded planning model. No data is being stored in SAC whatsoever. This scenario allows to:

  • Retain existing BPC / BW-IP models
  • Provide attractive & powerful UX to end users for:
    • Data entry
    • Analysis
    • Mobile iOS / Android apps (analysis only)
  • Use SAC Catalog for unified access to all content

What´s new with SAP BDC?

SAP BPC can be first migrated with BW into SAP BDC, modernizing data architecture. SAC can be introduced gradually, being a front end to existing SAP BPC embedded models and planning logic.

SCENARIO 3: ADD (Extend SAP BPC with SAC for new functional plans)

Picture 3: Extend SAP BPC with SAC for new functional plans

In this scenario, we can build new functional plans on top of SAP BPC with SAC and then we provide integration (data is replicated in both directions between SAP BPC and SAC). A simple example of such integration could be to bring an initial version of sales forecast from SAP BPC model into SAC model (model – dimensions & measures; with data is being replicated from SAP BPC into SAC). In the next step predictive time series forecasting would be applied on top of forecast data stored in SAC model. If needed, users could perform some manual adjustments or allocations and when done the updated forecast would be replicated back to SAP BPC model.

What´s new with SAP BDC?

As with Live scenario, SAP BPC can be first migrated with BW into SAP BDC, modernizing your data architecture. SAC can be introduced gradually, not only as front-end, but also as a planning engine, allowing phased transition into strategic solution.

For scenario 2+3 withing SAP BDC: BPC should be moved into BPC PCE of SAP BDC architecture.  This move is supported for BPC NetWeaver as well as BPC on BW/4HANA. See picture below:

Picture 4: Migration of SAP BPC versions to SAP BDC

 

BUT WHY MAKE THIS MOVE?

There are several strategic and technical benefits of SAP BPC PCE in SAP Business Data Cloud:

Strategic Benefits

  • Fully aligned with SAP Business Data Cloud
  • Follow the clean core principle: reduce custom extensions management costs
  • Application and technical operations from one vendor
  • Mainstream maintenance until 2030 for SAP BPC 10.1 and 2040 for SAP BPC 11  (BPC/4HANA)

Technical Benefits

  • Support for hybrid planning with both SAP BPC and SAC
  • Scalable platform
  • Continue to leverage SAP BW capabilities

FINAL THOUGHT

SAC/SAP BDC emerging as the new standard, now is the time to choose your path forward. Whether you go all-in on SAC, transition gradually via SAP BW PCE on SAP BDC, or start with seamless integration — SAP Business Data Cloud ensures your planning is built on a trusted, unified data foundation.

Would like to know more?

Check out the BPC MOVE blog series and this further information to learn more about the transition from SAP BPC to SAP Analytics Cloud:

  • Enabling BPC Runtime-license: https://launchpad.support.sap.com/#/notes/3150518The SAP Note 2969947provides you the latest information of the supported and unsupported planning functionalities when using an SAC Model based on a BPC Live connection.
  • Easily transition from BPC to SAC-P: https://www.sap.com/products/technology-platform/cloud-analytics/move-planning.html
  • SAP Note 3308697 with SAP BPC Standard Migration guide

Ready to take the next step?

Start your cloud migration journey. Contact us at movebpc@sap.com to learn more about using SAP Analytics Cloud for Planning to migrate your SAP BPC investment to the Cloud and accelerate your business & financial transformation.

Please check out also SAP Note 3308697 with SAP BPC Standard and BPC Embedded Migration guide (two migration guides pdfs).

(Fairly) new to SAP Analytics Cloud?

Find out how to apply the basics of modelling, planning, analysing and administration with SAP’s free learning resources on SAP Analytics Cloud. The learning journey is designed for business users who want to upskill and boost their careers. Check out even more role-based learning resources and opportunities to get certified in one place on SAP Learning site.

entry.title: Why the SAC Excel Add-in Matters
entry.content:
Introduction

In today's finance world, despite the rise of cloud platforms and AI-driven analytics, Excel remains deeply embedded in how finance teams work. Research suggests this isn't changing soon. Many organisations still rely on Excel alongside FP&A solutions and spreadsheets remain critical for flexibility, scenario building, and rapid adjustments.

From a consultant perspective, I see this reflected in SAP's product evolution as well. With cloud first strategy, the early years of SAC focused on strengthening core web features. Looking at the roadmap holistically, the last few years there seems a clear acceleration in the excel integration via SAC Excel Add-in as well. In the early years of SAC’s Excel Add-in, I was a bit cautious about recommending it to the clients because even the core features especially for planning were limited. Over the past 2–3 years, the add-in has matured significantly (with still some limitations in place).

Today, it is becoming a strong enabler for adoption in projects where finance teams depend heavily on Excel. Even in some areas, it provides greater flexibility. As an SAP Planning consultant, I personally love being able to use the SAP’s excel library along with excel formulas while designing flexible input templates.  In this blog, we’ll take a closer look at the SAC Excel Add-in’s core features, how to position it in projects, and where it fits into SAP’s roadmap for analytics.

The Evolution of Excel Integration in SAP Analytics

Excel integration is not new for SAP but it has been in the agenda for decades:

  • On-premise era: Excel based analytics tools like BEX Analyzer, BPC (EPM add-in) and Analysis for Office (AfO) run on premise.
  • Cloud-first shift: SAC was launched as a cloud-first product in 2015
  • Excel Integration for SAC accelerates: the first SAC Excel add-in appeared in 2020 with beta version with rapid investment in the upcoming years.

SAP makes it clear that its current strategy is cloud-first. In practice what we see in the FP&A project is a cloud first with Excel flexibility. The web interface remains the primary platform offering the full breadth of features including advanced visualisations, AI/ML capabilities, mobile access, collaboration features, workflows. However, I observed many clients still ask for excel integration especially for cases captured in below parts of the blog. SAP appears to have responded to this situation with the SAC Excel Add-in improving significantly. The add-in positioned as the strategic Excel interface for SAC going forward. 2025 July BI statement of direction confirms that AfO remains supported, (and the main excel interface for BW and BPC customers ), but no new features will be delivered. However, SAC Excel Add-in represents SAP's primary excel interface for cloud-based analytics and planning. More details are available along with comparison with AfO here

This positioning reflects a pragmatic approach: rather than forcing finance teams to abandon Excel entirely, SAC excel add in becomes a bridge that combines cloud platform benefits with the Excel interface that finance professionals know and trust.

 

Key Features, Benefits & Limitations

I've grouped the features into 3 comparing Excel Add-in capabilities with the web interface where relevant. Note that all features/limitations reflect the state as of September 2025. The Add-in evolves rapidly, so this focuses on core capabilities rather than an exhaustive list.

Planning & Data Entry

This is where the Excel Add-in has improved most significantly over the past two years with many core planning features now integrated making it a strong complement to the web interface.

  • Bulk data entry with excel formula support.

SAP excel add in supports mass data entry mode but single and fluid entry mode are available on web interface only. These entry modes provide some flexibility for different cases but I personally find “bulk data entry” in SAC excel add in quite smooth. It is not super easy to bring your offline excel data into SAC web templates although now you can copy-paste multiple cells with recent improvements. But real life scenarios require deeper excel integration with offline excel files. Let’s say an opex planner inputting budget data for 100 cost centers might maintain detailed driver calculations offline (regional KPIs, granular assumptions not in the central SAC model). In these type of cases, I have seen that the clients download web template to excel, blend it with their offline data and paste the output back to web. With the Excel Add-in, planners can use native Excel functions (VLOOKUP, FILTER etc.) directly within SAC-connected template to prepare and validate data before submission. This helps bridging the gap between centralized SAC planning models and the localized dataset that remain in Excel during implementations.

  • Top-down or bottom-up planning.

Disaggregation function is available on excel add in and works the same way with web. If the cells are empty, the system will disaggregate equally else proportionally.

  • Triggering SAC calculations

Triggering data actions are supported including selection parameters. Multi actions are not supported at the moment which makes some cross model copy / calculation steps less flexible but it is in roadmap for Q2-26

  • SAC Formula library for Excel

The SAC Excel Add-in provides SAC-specific formulas (functions with the SAP. prefix) that enable advanced template capabilities. For example, SAP.GETDATA fetches a specific dataset, which helps build reports at cell level. SAP.MEMBERPROPERTY returns the property value of a specific dimension in the frontend to consume these values further (such as version start and end date). There are many other formulas for specific scenarios.

Combining these SAC formulas with Excel's native formula library (IFs, VLOOKUPs, etc.) provides great flexibility. A powerful application of this flexibility is asymmetric filtering. For instance a finance planner starts the budget process with September closed actuals and needs an input template with 9 months actuals + 3 months forecast + 12 months budget (very typical), here the web's "forecast layout" functionality is quite helpful. However, asymmetric filtering in the SAC Excel Add-in takes this further allowing developers to manage different template sections independently, each with its own time horizon and formula logic. See this great blog for detailed guidance on asymmetric filter function in the SAC Excel Add-in.

  • Value Driver Tree: VDT is a web feature so it is not accessible in excel interface.
  • Comments : Data point comments are supported, but don't work on tables where asymmetric filter functionality is used
  • Calendar: Excel workbooks integrate with web-based calendars, but accessing the calendar requires the web interface

Analytics

The Excel Add-in focuses on tabular data analysis, giving finance users a familiar environment to explore SAC data with Excel's formatting and analytical capabilities. For dashboards and advanced visualizations, use the web interface—Excel is not a replacement for SAC's visualization layer

  • Core analytical operations : filters, drill-downs, sorting, and ranking available on SAC excel add in.
  • Formatting: Applying conditional formatting and thresholds are supported. Custom formatting is also possible supported by pre-built styling rules similar with AfO. You can select a master data in the table and apply specific format such as displaying actuals as grey (to highlight it is locked )while keeping other versions white.
  • High-volume mode will support more than 1 million cells soon (a planned Q4-25 only for analytics but not for planning).
  • Restricted measures are supported but calculated measures not yet. Although not the same thing, you can still use add rows / columns functionality and write formulas instead
  • AI / ML Features: Just ask, predictive planning, smart insights etc are accessed only via web add in
  • Advanced visualizations: Dashboards, charts, geo maps etc available on web only.

Collaboration Features

  • Excel add in is not supported on mobile devices. Works on desktop or web version of Office 365
  • Data point comments: Supported in Excel Add-in (with limitation: doesn't work with asymmetric table functionality)
  • Calendar: Excel workbooks integrate with web-based calendars; accessing calendar requires web interface
  • Discussion Panel: Chat is possible via chat only, not available on excel

 

When to Recommend the Excel Add-in

The Excel Add-in is not designed to replace the SAC web interface. Instead, it complements it by providing a familiar interface for Excel-dependent users. It can serve as an adoption enabler and a functional extension of SAC's capabilities.

Recommend the Excel Add-in for:

  • Bulk data preparation - Where finance teams need to manipulate large datasets, combine offline calculations with SAC data, use Excel functions to prepare data before submission.
  • Finance teams heavily reliant on excel - Finance teams who work primarily in Excel and would face significant change management challenges with a web-only interface.
  • Specific cases where excel add in provides more flexibility such as combining SAC's formula library with Excel's native capabilities enabling dynamic time horizons via asymmetric filtering described above.

Project guidance:

To maximize the value of the Excel Add-in:

  • Prototype early, ideally during the Explore phase. This allows you to position the Excel Add-in more accurately, identify which processes truly benefit, and set appropriate expectations with stakeholders.
  • Assess processes criticality. Not all planning processes require deep Excel integration—some may be better served by the web interface alone.
  • Frame it as 'SAC with Excel flexibility' rather than an either/or choice, emphasizing the web as the primary platform with Excel as a strategic complement for specific scenarios

 

Conclusion

Excel is not disappearing from finance. The SAC Excel Add-in addresses this reality by providing a bridge between modern SAC platform and the tool that finance teams trust. The add-in has evolved significantly over the past 2-3 years, with robust planning and core analytics capabilities that make it a genuine complement to the web interface, not a workaround.

In practice, its value goes beyond Excel-dependent teams or bulk data preparation. It also helps organisations manage change, easing the transition to cloud planning & analytics by letting users work in a familiar environment. Framing it as “SAC with Excel flexibility” where the web interface remains the primary platform creates the right balance between innovation and familiarity. This approach helps organisations modernise their planning and analytics while keeping the comfort and agility of Excel.

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud - Model Size Analysis in SAC
entry.content:
A Clearer View of Your Data: Introducing the New Model Size and Analysis Dashboard for SAP Analytics Cloud

For administrators and system owners of SAP Analytics Cloud, maintaining a high-performing and stable environment is a top priority. As organizations expand their use of SAC, managing the underlying data volumes becomes increasingly important.

A technical consideration in this context are the database tables, which have a system limit of 2 billion records. Reaching this limit has a significant consequence: it blocks all data publishing for planning models.

Until now, gaining proactive visibility into this data growth has been a challenge. Administrators often faced key questions without easy answers:

  • Which of our hundreds of models are the largest and contributing most to our data footprint?
  • Is the growth coming from transaction data, or is the audit log expanding rapidly?
  • In our largest models, which specific versions (e.g., Forecast, Budget 2025) are consuming the most space?

Today, we are pleased to introduce a solution designed to provide clear answers to these questions.

How to access: Open the story in your tenant by going to the Side Menu > Performance > Model Size Statistics and Analysis.

Introducing the "Model Size Statistics and Analysis" Dashboard

Available with the 2025.QRC4 release, we are delivering a new Story in SAC Content designed to give you the transparency and control you need to manage your SAC tenant's data footprint effectively. This Story serves as a central overview for monitoring, analyzing, and then to be able to take an informed action on data volumes before they become a critical issue.

Let's explore its key capabilities.

Key Capabilities: From Overview to Actionable Insight

This new Story empowers you with a multi-layered analytical approach:

Instantly Identify Your Largest Models

The dashboard presents a clear, ranked list of your Top 30 Models by total record count. This immediately answers the fundamental question: "Where is my data?" This allows you to focus your attention where it's needed most, without guesswork or manual checks.

Understand Data Composition with Category Breakdowns

Once you select a model, the dashboard reveals a breakdown by Data Category. You can clearly see the ratio of Transaction Data, Audit Data, Master Data, and more. This is crucial for understanding the nature of your model's size. Is it growing because of massive data loads, or is it the audit trail from frequent planning activities?

Uncover Version-Level Insights (Even in Large Models)

This is a significant enhancement. Previously, for models exceeding 100 million records, it was not possible to see the size of individual public versions within the Modeler. The Model Size and Analysis dashboard removes this limitation. You can now select a large model and see a clear chart showing which versions are the biggest contributors. This provides the information you need to target specific versions for cleanup or archiving

.

Correlate Growth with System Actions

The dashboard provides historical charts that track record growth over time. More importantly, it overlays this data with Import Jobs and Version Publish Events. You can now visually correlate a spike in data with a specific data load or a major publishing cycle, creating a clear cause-and-effect relationship. This helps you understand why and when your data is growing, enabling you to optimize your data management processes.

The Business Value: More Than Just Numbers

This dashboard delivers tangible business value by transforming how you manage your SAC environment:

  • Ensure Business Continuity: By proactively monitoring the Audit and Fact table limits, you can prevent a system-wide pause on planning operations, safeguarding critical business processes.
  • Enable Proactive Housekeeping: Move from a reactive to a proactive stance. Analyze data growth trends, identify old or unnecessary versions, and perform timely cleanup actions to keep your tenant lean and performant.
  • Create Actionable Transparency: The dashboard doesn't just provide data; it provides answers. You can now confidently explain data growth and justify housekeeping activities to business stakeholders.
  • Reduce Resource Consumption & Improve Performance: A well-maintained tenant with optimized data volumes naturally performs better. By cleaning up unnecessary data, you reduce the load on the system, leading to a better experience for all users.

Get started today! Once your tenant is updated to 2025.QRC4, explore this new content and take command of your data. Empower yourself with the insight to ensure your SAP Analytics Cloud environment remains stable, performant, and ready for the future.
